terminological: Of or pertaining to terminology.-- Ter`mi*no*log"ic*al*ly, adv.
theosophist: One addicted to theosophy.The theosophist is one who gives you a theory of God, or of the worksof God, which has not reason, but an inspiration of his own, for itsbasis. R. A. Vaughan.
tricuspid: Of or pertaining to the tricuspid valves; as, tricuspidobstruction. Tricuspid valve (Anat.), the valve, consisting of threetriangular membranous flaps, at the opening of the right auricle intothe right ventricle in the heart of most mammals; -- sometimes calledthe tricuspid valves, each flap being regarded as a valve.
tenability: The quality or state of being tenable; tenableness.
tomorrow: On the day after the present day; on the next day; on themorrow.Summon him to-morrow to the Tower. Shak.
tartar: A reddish crust or sediment in wine casks, consistingessentially of crude cream of tartar, and used in marking pure creamof tartar, tartaric acid, potassium carbonate, black flux, etc., and,in dyeing, as a mordant for woolen goods; -- called also argol, winestone, etc.
turn-buckle: The double cyanide of ferrous and ferric iron, a dark blueamorphous substance having a coppery luster, used in dyeing, calicoprinting, etc. Cf. Prussian blue, under Prussian.
tedious: Involving tedium; tiresome from continuance, prolixity,slowness, or the like; wearisome.-- Te"di*ous*ly, adv.-- Te"di*ous*ness, n.I see a man's life is a tedious one. Shak.I would not be tedious to the court. Bunyan.
thereon: On that or this. Chaucer.Then the king said, Hang him thereon. Esther vii. 9.
tole: To draw, or cause to follow, by displaying something pleasingor desirable; to allure by some bait. [Written also toll.]Whatever you observe him to be more frighted at then he should, tolehim on to by insensible degrees, till at last he masters thedifficulty.
terry: A kind of heavy colored fabric, either all silk, or silk andworsted, or silk and cotton, often called terry velvet, used forupholstery and trimmings.
troche: A medicinal tablet or lozenge; strictly, one of circular form.
tilia: A genus of trees, the lindens, the type of the family Tiliaceæ,distinguished by the winglike bract coalescent with the peduncle, andby the indehiscent fruit having one or two seeds. There are abouttwenty species, natives of temperate regions.  Many species areplanted as ornamental shade trees, and the tough fibrous inner barkis a valuable article of commerce. Also, a plant of this genus.
trilemma: A syllogism with three conditional propositions, the majorpremises of which are disjunctively affirmed in the minor. SeeDilemma.
tobie: A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered atone end. [Local, U. S.]
trichophore: The special cell in red algæ which produces or bears atrichogyne. See Illust. of Trichogyne.
temerity: Unreasonable contempt of danger; extreme venturesomeness;rashness; as, the temerity of a commander in war.
threadworm: Any long, slender nematode worm, especially the pinworm andfilaria.
thresh: Same as Thrash.He would thresh, and thereto dike and delve. Chaucer.
turnverein: A company or association of gymnasts and athletes.
torpedo station: A headquarters for torpedo vessels and their supplies, usuallyhaving facilities for repairs and for instruction and experiments.The principal torpedo station of the United States is at Newport,R.I.
tabulation: The act of forming into a table or tables; as, the tabulationof statistics.
thug: One of an association of robbers and murderers in India whopracticed murder by stealthy approaches, and from religious motives.They have been nearly exterminated by the British government.
tracheid: A wood cell with spiral or other markings and closedthroughout, as in pine wood.
torso: The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; insculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as,the torso of Hercules.
tombac: An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, and containingabout 84 per cent of copper; -- called also German, or Dutch, brass.It is very malleable and ductile, and when beaten into thin leaves issometimes called Dutch metal. The addition of arsenic makes whitetombac. [Written also tombak, and tambac.]
tormenting: Causing torment; as, a tormenting dream.-- Tor*ment"ing*ly, adv.
tenure: The manner of holding lands and tenements of a superior.
tedge: The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured;runner, geat.
tripinnatifid: Thrice pinnately cleft; -- said of a pinnatifid leaf when itssegments are pinnatifid, and the subdivisions of these also arepinnatifid.
tercentenary: Including, or relating to, an interval of three hundred years.-- n.
tentage: A collection of tents; an encampment. [Obs.] Drayton.
tubule: A minute tube lined with glandular epithelium; as, theuriniferous tubules of the kidney.
tercel: See Tiercel. Called also tarsel, tassel. Chaucer.
teretial: Rounded; as, the teretial tracts in the floor of the fourthventricle of the brain of some fishes. Owen.
tringa: A genus of limicoline birds including many species ofsandpipers. See Dunlin, Knot, and Sandpiper.
thionic: Of or pertaining to sulphur; containing or resembling sulphur;specifically, designating certain of the thio compounds; as, thethionic acids. Cf. Dithionic, Trithionic, Tetrathionic, etc.
thermogenic: Relating to heat, or to the production of heat; producing heat;thermogenous; as, the thermogenic tissues.
tried: imp. & p. p. of Try. Also adj.
taha: The African rufous-necked weaver bird (Hyphantornis texor).
tweezers: Small pinchers used to pluck out hairs, and for other purposes.
treillage: Latticework for supporting vines, etc.; an espalier; a trellis.Spectator.I shall plant the roses against my treillage to-morrow. Walpole.
troilite: Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoricirons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.
treacherous: Like a traitor; involving treachery; violating allegiance orfaith pledged; traitorous to the state or sovereign; perfidious inprivate life; betraying a trust; faithless.Loyal father of a treacherous son. Shak.The treacherous smile, a mask for secret hate. Cowper.
transposable: That may transposed; as, a transposable phrase.
telephony: The art or process of reproducing sounds at a distance, as withthe telephone.
topically: In a topical manner; with application to, or limitation of, aparticular place or topic.
tarboosh: A red cap worn by Turks and other Eastern nations, sometimesalone and sometimes swathed with linen or other stuff to make aturban. See Fez.
tautology: A repetition of the same meaning in different words; needlessrepetition of an idea in different words or phrases; a representationof anything as the cause, condition, or consequence of itself, as inthe following lines: --The dawn is overcast, the morning lowers, And heavily in cloudsbrings on the day. Addison.
tut-work: Work done by the piece, as in nonmetaliferous rock, the amountdone being usually reckoned by the fathom. Tomlinson.
tubiform: Having the form of a tube; tubeform. "Tubiform cells."Carpenter.
timeliness: The quality or state of being timely; seasonableness;opportuneness.
tabasheer: A concretion in the joints of the bamboo, which consistslargely or chiefly of pure silica. It is highly valued in the EastIndies as a medicine for the cure of bilious vomitings, bloody flux,piles, and various other diseases.
thorium: A metallic element found in certain rare minerals, as thorite,pyrochlore, monazite, etc., and isolated as an infusible graymetallic powder which burns in the air and forms thoria; -- formerlycalled also thorinum. Symbol Th. Atomic weight 232.0.
tangerine: A kind of orange, much like the mandarin, but of deeper colorand higher flavor. It is said to have been produced in America fromthe mandarin. [Written also tangierine.]
tuscaroras: A tribe of North American Indians formerly living on the Neuseand Tar rivers in North Carolina. They were conquered in 1713, afterwhich the remnant of the tribe joined the Five Nations, thus formingthe Six Nations. See Six Nations, under Six.
trimellic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a certain tribasic acid(called also trimellitic acid) metameric with trimesitic acid.
turnhalle: A building used as a school of gymnastics.
tittle-tattling: The act or habit of parting idly or gossiping.
toccata: An old form of piece for the organ or harpsichord, somewhat inthe free and brilliant style of the prelude, fantasia, or capriccio.
tussal: Pertaining to, or manifested by, cough.
thermosiphon: An arrangement of siphon tubes for assisting circulation in aliquid.
tongue: an organ situated in the floor of the mouth of most vertebratesand connected with the hyoid arch.
thurrok: The hold of a ship; a sink. [Obs.]Small drops of water that enter through a little crevice into thethurrok and into the bottom of a ship. Chaucer.
therf: Not fermented; unleavened; -- said of bread, loaves, etc.[Obs.]Pask and the feast of therf loaves. Wyclif.
trinitarianism: The doctrine of the Trinity; the doctrine that there are threedistinct persons in the Godhead.
thwartness: The quality or state of being thwart; obliquity; perverseness.
tacksman: One who holds a tack or lease from another; a tenant, orlessee. Sir W. Scott.The tacksmen, who formed what may be called the "peerage" of thelittle community, must be the captains. Macaulay.
tappet: A lever or projection moved by some other piece, as a cam, orintended to tap or touch something else, with a view to producechange or regulate motion. G. Francis. Tappet motion, a valve motionworked by tappets from a reciprocating part, without an eccentric orcam, -- used in steam pumps, etc.
tailboard: The board at the rear end of a cart or wagon, which can beremoved or let down, for convenience in loading or unloading.
terbium: A rare metallic element, of uncertain identification, supposedto exist in certain minerals, as gadolinite and samarskite, withother rare ytterbium earth. Symbol Tr or Tb. Atomic weight 150.
turanian: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an extensive family oflanguages of simple structure and low grade (called also Altaic,Ural-Altaic, and Scythian), spoken in the northern parts of Europeand Asia and Central Asia; of pertaining to, or designating, thepeople who speak these languages.
triangle: A figure bounded by three lines, and containing three angles.
transmigratory: Passing from one body or state to another.
torques: A cervical ring of hair or feathers, distinguished by its coloror structure; a collar.
them: The objective case of they. See They.Go ye rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves. Matt. xxv. 9.Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessedof my Father. Matt. xxv. 34.
tractarianism: The principles of the Tractarians, or of those personsaccepting the teachings of the "Tracts for the Times."
trundle-bed: A low bed that is moved on trundles, or little wheels, so thatit can be pushed under a higher bed; a truckle-bed; also, sometimes,a simiral bed without wheels. Chapman.
tatch: A spot or stain; also, a trick. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
trigeminous: Born three together; being one of three born at the same birth;also, threefold. E. Phillip
tomato: The fruit of a plant of the Nightshade family (Lycopersicumesculentun); also, the plant itself. The fruit, which is called alsolove apple, is usually of a rounded, flattened form, but oftenirregular in shape. It is of a bright red or yellow color, and iseaten either cooked or uncooked. Tomato gall (Zoöl.), a large gallconsisting of a mass of irregular swellings on the stems and leavesof grapevines. They are yellowish green, somewhat tinged with red,and produced by the larva of a small two-winged fly (Lasiopteravitis).-- Tomato sphinx (Zoöl.), the adult or imago of the tomato worm. Itclosely resembles the tobacco hawk moth. Called also tomato hawkmoth. See Illust. of Hawk moth.-- Tomato worm (Zoöl.), the larva of a large hawk moth (Sphinx, orMacrosila, quinquemaculata) which feeds upon the leaves of the tomatoand potato plants, often doing considerable damage. Called alsopotato worm.
tenderness: The quality or state of being tender (in any sense of theadjective).
trimness: The quality or state of being trim; orderliness; compactness;snugness; neatness.
transfluent: Passing or flowing through a bridge; -- said of water. Wright.
tackled: Made of ropes tacked together.My man shall be with thee, And bring thee cords made like a tackledstair. Shak.
tea-saucer: A small saucer in which a teacup is set.
tremor: A trembling; a shivering or shaking; a quivering or vibratorymotion; as, the tremor of a person who is weak, infirm, or old.He fell into an universal tremor of all his joints. Harvey.
tetravalent: Having a valence of four; tetratomic; quadrivalent.
tylopoda: A tribe of ungulates comprising the camels.
tropist: One who deals in tropes; specifically, one who avoids theliteral sense of the language of Scripture by explaining it as meretropes and figures of speech.
tenacity: The greatest longitudinal stress a substance can bear withouttearing asunder, -- usually expressed with reference to a unit areaof the cross section of the substance, as the number of pounds persquare inch, or kilograms per square centimeter, necessary to producerupture.
tessellate: To form into squares or checkers; to lay with checkered work.The floors are sometimes of wood, tessellated after the fashion ofFrance. Macaulay.
triphthong: A combination of three vowel sounds in a single syllable,forming a simple or compound sound; also, a union of three vowelcharacters, representing together a single sound; a trigraph; as,eye, -ieu in adieu, -eau in beau, are examples of triphthongs.
tapiroid: Allied to the tapir, or the Tapir family.
trim: To dress, as timber; to make smooth.
trifistulary: Having three pipes. Sir T. Browne.
tinman: A manufacturer of tin vessels; a dealer in tinware.
trundletail: A round or curled-up tail; also, a dog with such a tail. Shak.
talipot: A beautiful tropical palm tree (Corypha umbraculifera), anative of Ceylon and the Malabar coast. It has a trunk sixty orseventy feet high, bearing a crown of gigantic fan-shaped leaveswhich are used as umbrellas and as fans in ceremonial processions,and, when cut into strips, as a substitute for writing paper.
talmud: The body of the Jewish civil and canonical law not comprised inthe Pentateuch.
tractarian: One of the writers of the Oxford tracts, called "Tracts for theTimes," issued during the period 1833-1841, in which series of papersthe sacramental system and authority of the Church, and the value oftradition, were brought into prominence. Also, a member of the HighChurch party, holding generally the principles of the Tractarianwriters; a Puseyite.
tribe: A number of species or genera having certain structuralcharacteristics in common; as, a tribe of plants; a tribe of animals.
taskmaster: One who imposes a task, or burdens another with labor; onewhose duty is to assign tasks; an overseer. Ex. i. 11.All is, if I have grace to use it so, As ever in my greatTaskmaster's eye. Milton.
teacupful: As much as a teacup can hold; enough to fill a teacup.
transcribbler: A transcriber; -- used in contempt.He [Aristotle] has suffered vastly from the transcribblers, as allauthors of great brevity necessarily must. Gray.
transisthmian: Extending across an isthmus, as at Suez or Panama.
thimblerig: A sleight-of-hand trick played with three small cups, shapedlike thimbles, and a small ball or little pea.
typhomalarial: Pertaining to typhoid fever and malaria; as, typhomalarialfever, a form of fever having symptoms both of malarial and typhoidfever.
tonometry: The act of measuring with a tonometer; specifically (Med.),measurement of tension, esp. the tension of the eyeball.
tingid: Of or pertaining to the genus Tingis.
turdiformes: A division of singing birds including the thrushes and alliedkinds.
telpher: A contrivance for the conveyance of vehicles or loads by meansof electricity. Fleeming Jenkin. Telpher line, or Telpher road, anelectric line or road over which vehicles for carrying loads aremoved by electric engines actuated by a current conveyed by the line.
taverning: A feasting at taverns. [Obs.] "The misrule of our tavernings."Bp. Hall.
tanite: A firm composition of emery and a certain kind of cement, usedfor making grinding wheels, slabs, etc.
talc: A soft mineral of a soapy feel and a greenish, whitish, orgrayish color, usually occurring in foliated masses. It is hydroussilicate of magnesia. Steatite, or soapstone, is a compact granularvariety. Indurated talc, an impure, slaty talc, with a nearly compacttexture, and greater hardness than common talc; -- called also talcslate.
terminable: Capable of being terminated or bounded; limitable.-- Ter"mi*na*ble*ness, n. Terminable annuity, an annuity for astated, definite number of years; -- distinguished from life annuity,and perpetual annuity.
testament: A solemn, authentic instrument in writing, by which a persondeclares his will as to disposal of his estate and effects after hisdeath.
turpentine state: North Carolina; -- a nickname alluding to its extensiveproduction of turpentine.
totally: In a total manner; wholly; entirely.
trailing: a. & vb. n. from Trail. Trailing arbutus. (Bot.) See underArbutus.-- Trailing spring, a spring fixed in the axle box of the trailingwheels of a locomotive engine, and so placed as to assist indeadening any shock which may occur. Weale.-- Trailing wheel, a hind wheel of a locomotive when it is not adriving wheel; also, one of the hind wheels of a carriage.
tumultuariness: The quality or state of being tumultuary.
toparchy: A small state, consisting of a few cities or towns; a pettycountry governed by a toparch; as, Judea was formerly divided intoten toparchies. Fuller.
tripodian: An ancient stringed instrument; -- so called because, in form,it resembled the Delphic tripod.
token: A livid spot upon the body, indicating, or supposed toindicate, the approach of death. [Obs.]Like the fearful tokens of the plague, Are mere forerunners of theirends. Beau. & Fl.
trippet: A cam, wiper, or projecting piece which strikes another piecerepeatedly.
tenderfoot: A delicate person; one not inured to the hardship and rudenessof pioneer life. [Slang, Western U.S.]
tuum: Lit., thine; that which is thine; -- used in meum and tuum. See2d Meum.
teemless: Not fruitful or prolific; barren; as, a teemless earth.[Poetic] Dryden.
tincal: Crude native borax, formerly imported from Thibet. It was oncethe chief source of boric compounds. Cf. Borax.
tidy: The wren; -- called also tiddy. [Prov. Eng.]The tidy for her notes as delicate as they. Drayton.
tripetaloid: Having the form or appearance of three petals; appearing as iffurnished with three petals.
triturium: A vessel for separating liquids of different densities.[Written also tritorium.]
tolsester: A toll or tribute of a sextary of ale, paid to the lords ofsome manors by their tenants, for liberty to brew and sell ale.Cowell.
thinker: One who thinks; especially and chiefly, one who thinks in aparticular manner; as, a close thinker; a deep thinker; a coherentthinker.
tripudiation: The act of dancing. [R.] Bacon. Carlyle.
tutoress: A woman who performs the duties of a tutor; an instructress. E.Moore.
tregetry: Trickery; also, a trick. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
tyrociny: The state of being a tyro, or beginner; apprenticeship. [Obs.]Blount.
tapir: Any one of several species of large odd-toed ungulatesbelonging to Tapirus, Elasmognathus, and allied genera. They have along prehensile upper lip, short ears, short and stout legs, a short,thick tail, and short, close hair. They have three toes on the hindfeet, and four toes on the fore feet, but the outermost toe is oflittle use.
tetrastich: A stanza, epigram, or poem, consisting of four verses or lines.Pope.
tontine insurance: Insurance in which the benefits of the insurance aredistributed upon the tontine principle. Under the old, or fulltontine, plan, all benefits were forfeited on lapsed policies, on thepolicies of those who died within the tontine period only the face ofthe policy was paid without any share of the surplus, and thesurvivor at the end of the tontine period received the entiresurplus. This plan of tontine insurance has been replaced in theUnited States by the semitontine plan, in which the surplus isdivided among the holders of policies in force at the termination ofthe tontine period, but the reverse for the paid-up value is paid onlapsed policies, and on the policies of those that have died the faceis paid. Other modified forms are called free tontine, deferreddividend, etc., according to the nature of the tontine arrangement.
tiredness: The state of being tired, or weary.
toluate: A salt of any one of the toluic acids.
tew: To work hard; to strive; to fuse. [Local]
tetradymite: A telluride of bismuth. It is of a pale steel-gray color andmetallic luster, and usually occurs in foliated masses. Calles alsotelluric bismuth.
transvasate: To pour out of one vessel into another. [Obs.] Cudworth.
teleology: The doctrine of the final causes of things; specif. (Biol.),
tentory: The awning or covering of a tent. [Obs.] Evelyn.
tartarine: Potassium carbonate, obtained by the incineration of tartar.[Obs.]
triformity: The state of being triform, or of having a threefold shape.
tetrastyle: Having four columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, orcolonnade.-- n.
top-timbers: The highest timbers on the side of a vessel, being those abovethe futtocks. R. H. Dana, Jr.
thioxene: Any one of three possible metameric substances, which aredimethyl derivatives of thiophene, like the xylenes from benzene.
thulium: A rare metallic element of uncertain properties and identity,said to have been found in the mineral gadolinite.
tift: A fit of pettishness, or slight anger; a tiff.After all your fatigue you seem as ready for a tift with me as if youhad newly come from church. Blackwood's Mag.
theorizer: One who theorizes or speculates; a theorist.
toadstone: A local name for the igneous rocks of Derbyshire, England; --said by some to be derived from the German todter stein, meaning deadstone, that is, stone which contains no ores.
transmutationist: One who believes in the transmutation of metals or of species.
toponymy: A system of toponyms; the use of toponyms. -- To*pon"y*mal (#),Top`o*nym"ic (#), Top`o*nym"ic*al (#), a.
teaspoonful: As much as teaspoon will hold; enough to fill a teaspoon; --usually reckoned at a fluid dram or one quarter of a tablespoonful.
telpherage: The conveyance of vehicles or loads by means of electricity.Fleeming Jenkin.
tautological: Involving tautology; having the same signification; as,tautological expression.-- Tau`to*log"ic*al*ly, adv. Tautological echo, an echo that repeatsthe same sound or syllable many times.
thaumatolatry: Worship or undue admiration of wonderful or miraculous things.[R.]The thaumatolatry by which our theology has been debased for morethan a century. Hare.
tactual: Of or pertaining to the sense, or the organs, of touch; derivedfrom touch.In the lowest organisms we have a kind of tactual sense diffused overthe entire body. Tyndall.
transplace: To remove across some space; to put in an opposite or anotherplace. [R.]It [an obelisk] was transplaced . . . from the left side of theVatican into a more eminent place. Bp. Wilkins.
thwittle: To cut or whittle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Palsgrave.
thar: A goatlike animal (Capra Jemlaica) native of the Himalayas. Ithas small, flattened horns, curved directly backward. The hair of theneck, shoulders, and chest of the male is very long, reaching to theknees. Called also serow, and imo. [Written also thaar, and tahr.]
tanling: One tanned by the sun. [R.]Hot summer's tanlings and The shrinking slaves of winter. Shak.
triality: Three united; state of being three. [R.] H. Wharton.
tat: Gunny cloth made from the fiber of the Corchorus olitorius, orjute. [India]
tribometer: An instrument to ascertain the degree of friction in rubbingsurfaces. Brande & C.
thermo-: A combining form from Gr. qe`rmh heat, qermo`s hot, warm; as inthermochemistry, thermodynamic.
tubful: As much as a tub will hold; enough to fill a tub.
terebic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, terbenthene (oil ofturpentine); specifically, designating an acid, C7H10O4, obtained bythe oxidation of terbenthene with nitric acid, as a white crystallinesubstance.
toss: , v. t. [imp. & p. p. Tossed (; (less properly Tost ); p. pr. &vb. n. Tossing.] Etym: [ W. tosiaw, tosio, to jerk, toss, snatch,tosa quick jerk, a toss, a snatch. ]
taunt: Very high or tall; as, a ship with taunt masts. Totten.
trullization: The act of laying on coats of plaster with a trowel.
tartarian: The name of some kinds of cherries, as the Black Tartarian, orthe White Tartarian.
taenioglossa: An extensive division of gastropod mollusks in which theodontophore is long and narrow, and usually bears seven rows ofteeth. It includes a large number of families both marine and fresh-water.
trichobranchia: The gill of a crustacean in which the branchial filaments areslender and cylindrical, as in the crawfishes.
tetrahedrite: A sulphide of antimony and copper, with small quantities ofother metals. It is a very common ore of copper, and some varietiesyield a considerable presentage of silver. Called also gray copperore, fahlore, and panabase.
tarditation: Tardiness. [Obs.]To instruct them to avoid all snares of tarditation, in the Lord'saffairs. Herrick.
thomsonianism: An empirical system which assumes that the human body iscomposed of four elements, earth, air, fire, and water, and thatvegetable medicines alone should be used; -- from the founder, Dr.Samuel Thomson, of Massachusetts.
ten-strike: A knocking down of all ten pins at one delivery of the ball.[U. S.]
tank: A small Indian dry measure, averaging 240 grains in weight;also, a Bombay weight of 72 grains, for pearls. Simmonds.
tedesco: German; -- used chiefly of art, literature, etc.
tentwort: A kind of small fern, the wall rue. See under Wall.
tourmaline: A mineral occurring usually in three-sided or six-sided prismsterminated by rhombohedral or scalenohedral planes. Black tourmaline(schorl) is the most common variety, but there are also othervarieties, as the blue (indicolite), red (rubellite), also green,brown, and white. The red and green varieties when transparent arevalued as jewels. [Written also turmaline .]
toshred: To cut into shreads or pieces. [Obs.] Chaucer.
turnpike: A beam filled with spikes to obstruct passage; a cheval-de-frise. [R.] Turnpike man, a man who collects tolls at a turnpike.-- Turnpike road, a road on which turnpikes, or tollgates, areestablished by law, in order to collect from the users tolls todefray the cost of building, repairing, etc.
twinning: The assemblage of two or more crystals, or parts of crystals,in reversed position with reference to each other in accordance withsome definite law; also, rarely, in artificial twinning (accomplishedfor example by pressure), the process by which this reversal isbrought about. Polysynthetic twinning, repeated twinning of crystallamellæ, as that of the triclinic feldspars.-- Repeated twinning, twinning of more than two crystals, or partsof crystals.-- Twinning axis, Twinning plane. See the Note under Twin, n.
triableness: Quality or state of being triable.
tompon: An inking pad used in lithographic printing.
treadmill: A mill worked by persons treading upon steps on the peripheryof a wide wheel having a horizontal axis. It is used principally as ameans of prison discipline. Also, a mill worked by horses, dogs,etc., treading an endless belt.
tel-el-amarna: A station on the Nile, midway between Thebes and Memphis,forming the site of the capital of Amenophis IV., whose archivechamber was discovered there in 1887. A collection of tablets (calledthe Tel-el-Amarna, or the Amarna, tablets) was found here, formingthe Asiatic correspondence (Tel-el-Amarna letters) of Amenophis IV.and his father, Amenophis III., written in cuneiform characters. Itis an important source of our knowledge of Asia from about 1400 to1370 b. c..
tachometer: An instrument for measuring the velocity, or indicating changesin the velocity, of a moving body or substance. Specifically: --(a) An instrument for measuring the velocity of running water in ariver or canal, consisting of a wheel with inclined vanes, which isturned by the current. The rotations of the wheel are recorded byclockwork.(b) An instrument for showing at any moment the speed of a revolvingshaft, consisting of a delicate revolving conical pendulum which isdriven by the shaft, and the action of which by change of speed movesa pointer which indicates the speed on a graduated dial.(c) (Physiol.) An instrument for measuring the velocity of the blood;a hæmatachometer.
tesseraic: Diversified by squares; done in mosaic; tessellated. [Obs.] SirR. Atkyns (1712).
twelve: One more that eleven; two and ten; twice six; a dozen. Twelve-men's morris. See the Note under Morris.-- Twelve Tables. (Rom. Antiq.) See under Table.
trinal: Threefold. "Trinal unity." Milton.In their trinal triplicities on high. Spenser.
tithonometer: An instrument or apparatus for measuring or detectingtithonicity; an actinometer. [R.]
tachhydrite: A hydrous chloride of calcium and magnesium occurring inyellowish masses which rapidly deliquesce upon exposure. It is foundin the salt mines at Stassfurt.
tripping: Having the right forefoot lifted, the others remaining on theground, as if he were trotting; trippant; -- said of an animal, as ahart, buck, and the like, used as a bearing.
torsion galvanometer: A galvanometer in which current is measured by torsion.
tumor: A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of thebody; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; aneoplasm.
trilinear: Of, pertaining to, or included by, three lines; as, trilinearcoördinates.
triacid: Capable of neutralizing three molecules of a monobasic acid orthe equivalent; having three hydrogen atoms which may be acidradicals; -- said of certain bases; thus, glycerin is a triacid base.
tonite: An explosive compound; a preparation of gun cotton.
trocar: A stylet, usually with a triangular point, used for exploringtissues or for inserting drainage tubes, as in dropsy. [Written alsotrochar.]
tonka bean: The seed of a leguminous tree (Dipteryx odorata), native ofGuiana. It has a peculiarly agreeable smell, and is employed in thescenting of snuff. Called also tiononquin bean. [Written also toncabean, tonga bean.]
thyine wood: The fragrant and beautiful wood of a North African tree(Callitris quadrivalvis), formerly called Thuja articulata. The treeis of the Cedar family, and furnishes a balsamic resin calledsandarach. Rev. xviii. 12.
tautophonical: Pertaining to, or characterized by, tautophony; repeating thesame sound.
terrenity: Earthiness; worldliness. [Obs.] "A dull and low terrenity."Feltham.
thermocurrent: A current, as of electricity, developed, or set in motion, bythe action of heat.
tmesis: The separation of the parts of a compound word by theintervention of one or more words; as, in what place soever, forwhatsoever place.
townsfolk: The people of a town; especially, the inhabitants of a city, indistinction from country people; townspeople.
tibiotarsus: The large bone between the femur and tarsometatarsus in the legof a bird. It is formed by the union of the proximal part of thetarsus with the tibia.
tolerate: To suffer to be, or to be done, without prohibition orhindrance; to allow or permit negatively, by not preventing; not torestrain; to put up with; as, to tolerate doubtful practices.Crying should not be tolerated in children. Locke.We tolerate them because property and liberty, to a degree, requirethat toleration. Burke.
tralineate: To deviate; to stray; to wander. [Obs.] Dryden.
turncoat: One who forsakes his party or his principles; a renegade; anapostate.He is a turncoat, he was not true to his profession. Bunyan.
tonga: A drug useful in neuralgia, derived from a Fijian plantsupposed to be of the aroid genus Epipremnum.
tutorage: The office or occupation of a tutor; tutorship; guardianship.
telegraphoscope: An instrument for telegraphically transmitting a picture andreproducing its image as a positive or negative. The transmitterincludes a camera obscura and a row of minute selenium cells. Thereceiver includes an oscillograph, ralay, equilibrator, and aninduction coil the sparks from which perforate a paper with tinyholes that form the image.
torchlight: The light of a torch, or of torches. Also adjectively; as, atorchlight procession.
tournery: Work turned on a lathe; turnery.[Obs.] See Turnery. Evelyn.
transportability: The quality or state of being transportable.
telestich: A poem in which the final letters of the lines, takenconsequently, make a name. Cf. Acrostic.
thrush: Any one of numerous species of singing birds belonging toTurdus and allied genera. They are noted for the sweetness of theirsongs.
therapeutae: A name given to certain ascetics said to have anciently dweltin the neighborhood of Alexandria. They are described in a workattributed to Philo, the genuineness and credibility of which are nowmuch discredited.
thunderworm: A small, footless, burrowing, snakelike lizard (RhineuraFloridana) allied to Amphisbæna, native of Florida; -- so calledbecause it leaves its burrows after a thundershower.
tucan: The Mexican pocket gopher (Geomys Mexicanus). It resembles thecommon pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger.Called also tugan, and tuza.
tarragon: A plant of the genus Artemisa (A. dracunculus), much used inFrance for flavoring vinegar.
tanager: Any one of numerous species of bright-colored singing birdsbelonging to Tanagra, Piranga, and allied genera. The scarlet tanager(Piranga erythromelas) and the summer redbird (Piranga rubra) arecommon species of the United States.
traditionalism: A system of faith founded on tradition; esp., the doctrine thatall religious faith is to be based solely upon what is delivered fromcompetent authority, exclusive of rational processes.
thearchic: Divinely sovereign or supreme. [R.]He [Jesus] is the thearchic Intelligence. Milman.
tantrum: A whim, or burst of ill-humor; an affected air. [Colloq.]Thackeray.
thor: The god of thunder, and son of Odin.
tartaric: Of or pertaining to tartar; derived from, or resembling,tartar. Tartaric acid. (a) An acid widely diffused throughout thevegetable kingdom, as in grapes, mountain-ash berries, etc., andobtained from tartar as a white crystalline substance,C2H2(OH)2.(CO2H)2, having a strong pure acid taste. It is used inmedicine, in dyeing, calico printing, photography, etc., and also asa substitute for lemon juice. Called also dextro-tartaric acid. (b)By extension, any one of the series of isomeric acids (racemic acid,levotartaric acid, inactive tartaric acid) of which tartaric acidproper is the type.
thrustle: The throstle, or song thrust. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]When he heard the thrustel sing. Chaucer.
tolerance: The power possessed or acquired by some persons of bearingdoses of medicine which in ordinary cases would prove injurious orfatal. Tolerance of the mint. (Coinage) Same as Remedy of the mint.See under Remedy.
twelvepenny: , Sold for a shilling; worth or costing a shilling.
trot: To cause to move, as a horse or other animal, in the pacecalled a trot; to cause to run without galloping or cantering. Totrot out, to lead or bring out, as a horse, to show his paces; hence,to bring forward, as for exhibition. [Slang.]
tree: Any perennial woody plant of considerable size (usually overtwenty feet high) and growing with a single trunk.
teamed: Yoked in, or as in, a team. [Obs.]Let their teamed fishes softly swim. Spenser.
toughness: The quality or state of being tough.
torment: An engine for casting stones. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
tetterous: Having the character of, or pertaining to, tetter.
telephone exchange: A central office in which the wires of telephones may beconnected to permit conversation.
turbinella: A genus of large marine gastropods having a thick heavy shellwith conspicuous folds on the columella.
thessalian: Of or pertaining to Thessaly in Greece. Shak.-- n.
temple: A contrivence used in a loom for keeping the web stretchedtransversely.
troublous: Full of trouble; causing trouble. "In doubtful time oftroublous need." Byron.A tall ship tossed in troublous seas. Spenser.
tumble: Act of tumbling, or rolling over; a fall.
thallene: A hydrocarbon obtained from coal-tar residues, and remarkablefor its intense yellowish green fluorescence.
trochaic: A trochaic verse or measure. Dryden.
targeted: Furnished, armed, or protected, with a target.
tormentor: An implement for reducing a stiff soil, resembling a harrow,but running upon wheels. Hebert.
typical: Combining or exhibiting the essential characteristics of agroup; as, a typical genus.-- Typ"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Typ"ic*al*ness, n.
tipcart: A cart so constructed that the body can be easily tipped, inorder to dump the load.
teleosaurus: A genus of extinct crocodilian reptiles of the Jurassic period,having a long and slender snout.
teemer: One who teems, or brings forth.
taverner: One who keeps a tavern. Chaucer. Camden.
tegula: A small appendage situated above the base of the wings ofHymenoptera and attached to the mesonotum.
tampoon: The stopper of a barrel; a bung.
trachinoid: Of, pertaining to, or like, Trachinus, a genus of fishes whichincludes the weevers. See Weever.
terebinthic: Of or pertaining to turpentine; resembling turpentine;terbinthine; as, terbinthic qualities.
tumulosity: The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness. [R.] Bailey.
trigesimo-secundo: Having thirty-two leaves to a sheet; as, a trigesimo-secundoform, book, leaf, size, etc.
tub: To plant or set in a tub; as, to tub a plant.
twopence: A small coin, and money of account, in England, equivalent totwo pennies, -- minted to a fixed annual amount, for almsgiving bythe sovereign on Maundy Thursday.
triptych: Anything in three parts or leaves. Specifically: --(a) A writing tablet in three parts, two of which fold over on themiddle part.(b) A picture or altarpiece in three compartments.
thimbleberry: A kind of black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis), common inAmerica.
titanium: An elementary substance found combined in the mineralsmanaccanite, rutile, sphene, etc., and isolated as an infusible iron-gray amorphous powder, having a metallic luster. It burns when heatedin the air. Symbol Ti. Atomic weight 48.1.
trachea: The windpipe. See Illust. of Lung.
thalassography: The study or science of the life of marine organisms. Agassiz.
twinner: One who gives birth to twins; a breeder of twins. Tusser.
trophy: A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle,or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimestrophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
tirrit: A word from the vocabulary of Mrs. Quickly, the hostess inShakespeare's Henry IV., probably meaning terror.
tidal: Of or pertaining to tides; caused by tides; having tides;periodically rising and falling, or following and ebbing; as, tidalwaters.The tidal wave of deeper souls Into our inmost being rolls, And liftsus unawares Out of all meaner cares. Longfellow.Tidal air (Physiol.), the air which passes in and out of the lungs inordinary breathing. It varies from twenty to thirty cubic inches.-- Tidal basin, a dock that is filled at the rising of the tide.-- Tidal wave. (a) See Tide wave, under Tide. Cf. 4th Bore. (b) Avast, swift wave caused by an earthquake or some extraordinarycombination of natural causes. It rises far above high-water mark andis often very destructive upon low-lying coasts.
thorough-lighted: Provided with thorough lights or windows at opposite sides, asa room or building. Gwilt.
tradeful: Full of trade; busy in traffic; commercial. Spenser.
tyrannish: Like a tyrant; tyrannical. [Obs.] "The proud tyrannish Roman."Gower.
theobromine: An alkaloidal ureide, C7H8N4O2, homologous with and resemblingcaffeine, produced artificially, and also extracted from cacao andchocolate (from Theobroma Cacao) as a bitter white crystallinesubstance; -- called also dimethyl xanthine.
truth-lover: One who loves the truth.Truth-lover was our English Duke. Tennyson.
triangularity: The quality or state of being triangular. Bolingbroke.
telespectroscope: A spectroscope arranged to be attached to a telescope forobservation of distant objects, as the sun or stars. Lockyer.
terminism: The doctrine held by the Terminists.
toe hold: A hold in which the agressor bends back his opponent's foot.
trousseau: The collective lighter equipments or outfit of a bride,including clothes, jewelry, and the like; especially, that which isprovided for her by her family.
telemeter: An instrument used for measuring the distance of an object froman observer; as, a telescope with a micrometer for measuring theapparent diameter of an object whose real dimensions are known.
tracer: One who, or that which, traces.
tarente: A harmless lizard of the Gecko family (PlatydactylusMauritianicus) found in Southern Europe and adjacent countries,especially among old walls and ruins.
thermometrically: In a thermometrical manner; by means of a thermometer.
truthy: Truthful; likely; probable. [R.] "A more truthy import." W. G.Palgrave.
tampoe: The edible fruit of an East Indian tree (Baccaurea Malayana) ofthe Spurge family. It somewhat resembles an apple.
talmudism: The teachings of the Talmud, or adherence to them.
taciturnity: Habilual silence, or reserve in speaking.The cause of Addison's taciturnity was a natural diffidence in thecompany of strangers. V. Knox.The taciturnity and the short answers which gave so much offense.Macaulay.
tusky: Having tusks. "The scar indented by the tusky oar." Dryden.
taintless: Free from taint or infection; pure.
targum: A translation or paraphrase of some portion of the OldTestament Scriptures in the Chaldee or Aramaic language or dialect.
timocratic: Belonging to, or constituted by, timocracy. Sir G. C. Lewis.
trijugate: In three pairs; as, a trijugate leaf, or a pinnate leaf withthree pairs of leaflets.
transported: Conveyed from one place to another; figuratively, carried awaywith passion or pleasure; entranced.-- Trans*port"ed*ly, adv.-- Trans*port"ed*ness, n.
theologian: A person well versed in theology; a professor of theology ordivinity; a divine.
tectorial: Of or pertaining to covering; -- applied to a membraneimmediately over the organ of Corti in the internal ear.
tomentum: The closely matted hair or downy nap covering the leaves orstems of some plants.
thuggee: The practice of secret or stealthy murder by Thugs. "One of thesuppressors of Thuggee." J. D. Hooker.
tottlish: Trembling or tottering, as if about to fall; un steady.[Colloq. U.S.]
trinodal: Having three knots or nodes; having three points from which aleaf may shoot; as, a trinodal stem.
toreumatography: A description of sculpture such as bas-relief in metal.
translation: A transfer of meaning in a word or phrase, a metaphor; atralation. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
tetroxide: An oxide having four atoms of oxygen in the molecule; aquadroxide; as, osmium tetroxide, OsO.
tetrabranchiate: Of or pertaining to the Tetrabranchiata.-- n.
tubinares: A tribe of sea birds comprising the petrels, shearwaters,albatrosses, hagdons, and allied birds having tubular horny nostrils.
transalpine: Being on the farther side of the Alps in regard to Rome, thatis, on the north or west side of the Alps; of or pertaining to theregion or the people beyond the Alps; as, transalpine Gaul; --opposed to cisalpine. " Transalpine garbs." Beau. & Fl.
thermochroic: Pert. to or designating heat rays that have undergone selectiveabsorption and are therefore analogous to colored light rays.
trapes: A slattern; an idle, sluttish, or untidy woman. [Obs. orColloq.]
tsetse: A venomous two-winged African fly (Glossina morsitans) whosebite is very poisonous, and even fatal, to horses and cattle, butharmless to men. It renders extensive districts in which it aboundsuninhabitable during certain seasons of the year. [Written alsotzetze, and tsetze.]
tentacle: A more or less elongated process or organ, simple or branched,proceeding from the head or cephalic region of invertebrate animals,being either an organ of sense, prehension, or motion. Tentaclesheath (Zoöl.), a sheathlike structure around the base of thetentacles of many mollusks.
transitory: Continuing only for a short time; not enduring; fleeting;evanescent.Comfort and succor all those who, in this transitory life, are introuble. Bk. of Com. Prayer.It was not the transitory light of a comet, which shines and glowsfor a wile, and then . . . vanishes into nothing. South.Transitory action (Law), an action which may be brought in anycounty, as actions for debt, and the like; -- opposed to localaction. Blackstone. Bouvier.
titleless: Not having a title or name; without legitimate title. "Atitleless tyrant." Chaucer.
transfix: To pierce through, as with a pointed weapon; to impale; as, totransfix one with a dart.
tenantless: Having no tenants; unoccupied; as, a tenantless mansion. Shak.
torqued: Twisted; bent; -- said of a dolphin haurient, which forms afigure like the letter S.
throne: A high order of angels in the celestial hierarchy; -- a meaninggiven by the schoolmen. Milton.Great Sire! whom thrones celestial ceaseless sing. Young.
tarot: A game of cards; -- called also taroc. Hoyle.
teneriffe: A white wine resembling Madeira in taste, but more tart,produced in Teneriffe, one of the Canary Islands; -- called alsoVidonia.
torsion meter: An instrument for determining the torque on a shaft, and hencethe horse power of an engine, esp. of a marine engine of high power,by measuring the amount of twist of a given length of the shaft.Called also torsimeter, torsiometer, torsometer.
tribute: A certain proportion of the ore raised, or of its value, givento the miner as his recompense. Pryce. Tomlinson. Tribute money,money paid as a tribute or tax.-- Tribute pitch. (Mining) See under Tributer. [Eng.]
thoroughpaced: Perfect in what is undertaken; complete; going all lengths; as,a thoroughplaced Tory or Whig.If she be a thoroughplaced impostor. Sir W. Scott.
tool steel: Hard steel, usually crucible steel, capable of being temperedso as to be suitable for tools.
turnus: A common, large, handsome, American swallowtail butterfly, nowregarded as one of the forms of Papilio, or Jasoniades, glaucus. Thewings are yellow, margined and barred with black, and with an orange-red spot near the posterior angle of the hind wings. Called alsotiger swallowtail. See Illust. under Swallowtail.
trust company: Any corporation formed for the purpose of acting as trustee.Such companies usually do more or less of a banking business.
tropeine: Any one of a series of artificial ethereal salts derived fromthe alkaloidal base tropine.
timelessly: In a timeless manner; unseasonably. [R.] Milton.
tripetalous: Having three petals, or flower leaves; three-petaled.
toilful: Producing or involving much toil; laborious; toilsome; as,toilful care. Mickle.
trophosome: The nutritive zooids of a hydroid, collectively, asdistinguished from the gonosome, or reproductive zooids.
tephrosia: A genus of leguminous shrubby plants and herbs, mostly found intropical countries, a few herbaceous species being North American.The foliage is often ashy-pubescent, whence the name.
truster: One who makes a trust; -- the correlative of trustee.
ternate: Having the parts arranged by threes; as, ternate branches,leaves, or flowers.-- Ter"nate*ly, adv.
tilde: The accentual mark placed over n, and sometimes over l, inSpanish words [thus, ñ, l], indicating that, in pronunciation, thesound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of theinitial, or consonantal, y.
tribal: Of or pertaining to a tribe or tribes; as, a tribal scepter.Bp. Warburton.
treasure-trove: Any money, bullion, or the like, found in the earth, orotherwise hidden, the owner of which is not known. In England suchtreasure belongs to the crown; whereas similar treasure found in thesea, or upon the surface of the land, belongs to the finder if noowner appears.
top out: To top off; to finish by putting on a cap of top (uppermost)course (called a top`ping-out" course).
teraconic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thedistillation of terebic acid, and homologous with citraconic acid.
tubicolous: Inhabiting a tube; as, tubicolous worms.
trammeled: Having blazes, or white marks, on the fore and hind foot of oneside, as if marked by trammels; -- said of a horse. [Written alsotrammelled.]
twinge: To have a sudden, sharp, local pain, like a twitch; to suffer akeen, darting, or shooting pain; as, the side twinges.
tirade: A declamatory strain or flight of censure or abuse; a ramblinginvective; an oration or harangue abounding in censorious and bitterlanguage.Here he delivers a violent tirade against persons who profess to knowanything about angels. Quarterly Review.
tremolite: A white variety of amphibole, or hornblende, occurring in long,bladelike crystals, and coarsely fibrous masses.
triniunity: Triunity; trinity. [Obs.]As for terms of trinity, triniunity, . . . and the like, they rejectthem as scholastic notions. Milton.
thistle: Any one of several prickly composite plants, especially thoseof the genera Cnicus, Craduus, and Onopordon. The name is often alsoapplied to other prickly plants. Blessed thistle, Carduus benedictus,so named because it was formerly considered an antidote to the biteof venomous creatures.-- Bull thistle, Cnicus lanceolatus, the common large thistle ofneglected pastures.-- Canada thistle, Cnicus arvensis, a native of Europe, butintroduced into the United States from Canada.-- Cotton thistle, Onopordon Acanthium.-- Fuller's thistle, the teasel.-- Globe thistle, Melon thistle, etc. See under Globe, Melon, etc.-- Pine thistle, Atractylis gummifera, a native of the Mediterraneanregion. A vicid gum resin flows from the involucre.-- Scotch thistle, either the cotton thistle, or the musk thistle,or the spear thistle; -- all used national emblems of Scotland.-- Sow thistle, Sonchus oleraceus.-- Spear thistle. Same as Bull thistle.-- Star thistle, a species of Centaurea. See Centaurea.-- Torch thistle, a candelabra-shaped plant of the genus Cereus. SeeCereus.-- Yellow thistle, Cincus horridulus. Thistle bird (Zoöl.), theAmerican goldfinch, or yellow-bird (Spinus tristis); -- so called onaccount of its feeding on the seeds of thistles. See Illust. underGoldfinch.-- Thistle butterfly (Zoöl.), a handsomely colored Americanbutterfly (Vanessa cardui) whose larva feeds upon thistles; -- calledalso painted lady.-- Thistle cock (Zoöl.), the corn bunting (Emberiza militaria).[Prov. Eng.] -- Thistle crown, a gold coin of England of the reign ofJames I., worth four shillings.-- Thistle finch (Zoöl.), the goldfinch; -- so called from itsfondness for thistle seeds. [Prov. Eng.] -- Thistle funnel, a funnelhaving a bulging body and flaring mouth.
tattler: Any one of several species of large, long-legged sandpipersbelonging to the genus Totanus.
top-block: A large ironbound block strapped with a hook, and, when used,hung to an eyebolt in the cap, -- used in swaying and lowering thetopmast. Totten.
tampon: A plug introduced into a natural or artificial cavity of thebody in order to arrest hemorrhage, or for the application ofmedicine.
tardigradous: Moving slowly; slow-paced. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
transpalatine: Situated beyond or outside the palatine bone; -- said of a bonein the skull of some reptiles.
tetradynamian: A plant of the order Tetradynamia.
tonsilotome: An instrument for removing the tonsils.
telephotographic: Designating, or pertaining to, the process of telephotography.
tabefy: To cause to waste gradually, to emaciate. [R.]  Harvey.
top rake: The angle that the front edge of the point of a tool is setback from the normal to the surface being cut.
tac-au-tac: The parry which is connected with a riposte; also, a series ofquick attacks and parries in which neither fencer gains a point.
toxotes: A genus of fishes comprising the archer fishes. See Archerfish.
trichopterous: Of, pertaining to, or characterizing, the Trichoptera.
thiefly: Like a thief; thievish; thievishly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
text-hand: A large hand in writing; -- so called because it was thepractice to write the text of a book in a large hand and the notes ina smaller hand.
tractator: One who writes tracts; specif., a Tractarian. [R.] C. Kingsley.
tut: Be still; hush; -- an exclamation used for checking orrebuking.
twire: A twisted filament; a thread. [Obs.] Locke.
temperamental: Of or pertaining to temperament; constitutional. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
troubadour: One of a school of poets who flourished from the eleventh tothe thirteenth century, principally in Provence, in the south ofFrance, and also in the north of Italy. They invented, and especiallycultivated, a kind of lyrical poetry characterized by intricacy ofmeter and rhyme, and usually of a romantic, amatory strain.
tropilidene: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the dry distillation oftropine with quicklime. It is regarded as being homologous withdipropargyl.
terminus: The Roman divinity who presided over boundaries, whose statuewas properly a short pillar terminating in the bust of a man, woman,satyr, or the like, but often merely a post or stone stuck in theground on a boundary line.
tocsin: An alarm bell, or the ringing of a bell for the purpose ofalarm.The loud tocsin tolled their last alarm. Campbell.
trommel: A revolving buddle or sieve for separating, or sizing, ores.Raymond.
te-hee: A tittering laugh; a titter. "'Te-hee,' quoth she." Chaucer.
tucket: A slight flourish on a trumpet; a fanfare. [Obs.] Tucketsonance, the sound of the tucket. [Obs.]Let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount.Shak.
teratoid: Resembling a monster; abnormal; of a pathological growth,exceedingly complex or highly organized. S. D. Gross.
toll: To take away; to vacate; to annul.
thyrohyal: One of the lower segments in the hyoid arch, often consolidatedwith the body of the hyoid bone and forming one of its great horns,as in man.
topmost: Highest; uppermost; as, the topmost cliff; the topmost branchof a tree.The nightngale may claim the topmost bough. Cowper.
taxis: Manipulation applied to a hernial tumor, or to an intestinalobstruction, for the purpose of reducing it. Dunglison.
tonguy: Ready or voluble in speaking; as, a tonguy speaker. [Writtenalso tonguey.] [Colloq.]
tewtaw: To beat; to break, as flax or hemp. [Obs.] Mortimer.
tenesmic: Of or pertaining to tenesmus; characterized by tenesmus.
tapster: One whose business is to tap or draw ale or other liquor.
transfusible: Capable of being transfused; transferable by transfusion.
tautegorical: Expressing the same thing with different words; -- opposed toallegorical. [R.] Coleridge.
tigella: That part of an embryo which represents the young stem; thecaulicle or radicle.
troubler: One who troubles or disturbs; one who afflicts or molests; adisturber; as, a troubler of the peace.The rich troublers of the world's repose. Waller.
tetraspermous: Having four seeds. Tetraspermous plant, a plant which producesfour seeds in each flower.
tiglic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7CO2H (calledalso methyl crotonic acid), homologous with crotonic acid, andobtained from croton oil (from Croton Tiglium) as a white crystallinesubstance.
tut-mouthed: Having a projecting under jaw; prognathous. [Obs.] Holland.
thermostat: A self-acting apparatus for regulating temperature by theunequal expansion of different metals, liquids, or gases by heat, asin opening or closing the damper of a stove, or the like, as the heatbecomes greater or less than is desired.
teyne: A thin plate of metal. [Obs.] "A teyne of silver." Chaucer.
tamias: A genus of ground squirrels, including the chipmunk.
tropology: A rhetorical mode of speech, including tropes, or changes fromthe original import of the word. Sir T. Browne.
trioctile: An aspect of two planets with regard to the earth when they arethree octants, or three eighths of a circle, that is, 135 degrees,distant from each other. Hutton.
teutonic: The language of the ancient Germans; the Teutonic languages,collectively.
tern: Any one of numerous species of long-winged aquatic birds,allied to the gulls, and belonging to Sterna and various alliedgenera.
thaw: To cause (frozen things, as earth, snow, ice) to melt, soften,or dissolve.
thrasonical: Of or pertaining to Thraso; like, or becoming to, Thraso;bragging; boastful; vainglorious.-- Thra*son"ic*al*ly, adv.Cæsar's thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame.' Shak.
taxidermic: Of or pertaining to the art of preparing and preserving theskins of animals.
thermantidote: A device for circulating and cooling the air, consistingessentially of a kind of roasting fan fitted in a window and incasedin wet tatties. [India]
trimethyl: (Chem.) A prefix or combining form (also used adjectively)indicating the presence of three methyl groups.
trollmydames: The game of nineholes. [Written also trolmydames.] [Obs.] Shak.
tomopteris: A genus of transparent marine annelids which swim actively atthe surface of the sea. They have deeply divided or forked finlikeorgans (parapodia). This genus is the type of the order, or suborder,Gymnocopa.
torpidness: The qualityy or state of being torpid.
tunnel: A level passage driven across the measures, or at right anglesto veins which it is desired to reach; -- distinguished from thedrift, or gangway, which is led along the vein when reached by thetunnel. Tunnel head (Metal.), the top of a smelting furnace where thematerials are put in.-- Tunnel kiln, a limekiln in which coal is burned, as distinguishedfrom a flame kiln, in which wood or peat is used.-- Tunnel net, a net with a wide mouth at one end and narrow at theother.-- Tunnel pit, Tunnel shaft, a pit or shaft sunk from the top of theground to the level of a tunnel, for drawing up the earth and stones,for ventilation, lighting, and the like.
tangent: A tangent line curve, or surface; specifically, that portion ofthe straight line tangent to a curve that is between the point oftangency and a given line, the given line being, for example, theaxis of abscissas, or a radius of a circle produced. SeeTrigonometrical function, under Function. Artificial, or Logarithmic,tangent, the logarithm of the natural tangent of an arc.-- Natural tangent, a decimal expressing the length of the tangentof an arc, the radius being reckoned unity.-- Tangent galvanometer (Elec.), a form of galvanometer having acircular coil and a short needle, in which the tangent of the angleof deflection of the needle is proportional to the strength of thecurrent.-- Tangent of an angle, the natural tangent of the arc subtending ormeasuring the angle.-- Tangent of an arc, a right line, as ta, touching the arc of acircle at one extremity a, and terminated by a line ct, passing fromthe center through the other extremity o.
theologaster: A pretender or quack in theology. [R.] Burton.
telic: Denoting the final end or purpose, as distinguished fromecbatic. See Ecbatic. Gibbs.
twaddler: One who prates in a weak and silly manner, like one whosefaculties are decayed.
telestereograph: An instrument for telegraphically reproducing a photograph. --Tel`e*ste`re*og"ra*phy (#), n.
triseralous: Having three sepals, or calyx leaves.
toft: A place where a messuage has once stood; the site of a burnt ordecayed house.
threaten: To use threats, or menaces; also, to have a threateningappearance.Though the seas threaten, they are merciful. Shak.
turonian: One of the subdivisions into which the Upper Cretaceousformation of Europe is divided.
tivy: With great speed; -- a huntsman's word or sound. Dryden.
truceless: Without a truce; unforbearing.Two minds in one, and each a truceless guest. H. Brooke.
tangential: Of or pertaining to a tangent; in the direction of a tangent.Tangential force (Mech.), a force which acts on a moving body in thedirection of a tangent to the path of the body, its effect being toincrease or diminish the velocity; -- distinguished from a normalforce, which acts at right angles to the tangent and changes thedirection of the motion without changing the velocity.-- Tangential stress. (Engin.) See Shear, n., 3.
transfuse: To transfer, as blood, from the veins or arteries of one man oranimal to those of another.
tithonicity: The state or property of being tithonic; actinism. [R.]
torpedo boom: A spar formerly carried by men-of-war, having a torpedo on itsend.
tetrapneumona: A division of Arachnida including those spiders which have fourlungs, or pulmonary sacs. It includes the bird spiders (Mygale) andthe trapdoor spiders. See Mygale.
turmerol: Turmeric oil, a brownish yellow, oily substance extracted fromturmeric by ligroin.
taxable: That may be legally charged by a court against the plaintiff ofdefendant in a suit; as, taxable costs.-- Tax"a*ble*ness, n.-- Tax"a*bly, adv.
tallowy: Of the nature of tallow; resembling tallow; greasy.
tagliacotain: Of or pertaining to Tagliacozzi, a Venetian surgeon; as, theTagliacotian operation, a method of rhinoplasty described by him.[Also Taliacotian, and Tagliacozzian.]
toque: A variety of the bonnet monkey.
tissue: One of the elementary materials or fibres, having a uniformstructure and a specialized function, of which ordinary animals andplants are composed; a texture; as, epithelial tissue; connectivetissue.
tump: A little hillock; a knoll. Ainsworth.
thorntail: A beautiful South American humming bird (Gouldia Popelairii),having the six outer tail feathers long, slender, and pointed. Thehead is ornamented with a long, pointed crest.
tag day: A day on which contributions to some public or private charityor fund are solicited promiscuously on the street, and tags given tocontributors to wear as an evidence of their having contributed. Suchsolicitation is now subject to legal restriction in various places.
two-port: Having two ports; specif.: Designating a type of two-cycleinternal-combustion engine in which the admission of the mixture tothe crank case is through a suction valve.
top-tackle: A tackle used in hoisting and lowering the topmast.
tenthredinides: A group of Hymneoptera comprising the sawflies.
torch race: A race by men carrying torches, as in ancient Greece.
turcism: A mode of speech peculiar to the Turks; a Turkish idiom orexpression; also, in general, a Turkish mode or custom.
testiness: The quality or state of being testy; fretfulness; petulance.Testiness is a disposition or aptness to be angry. Locke.
trekker: One that treks. [Written also trecker.] [South Africa]  JamesBryce.
thienone: A ketone derivative of thiophene obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, (C4H3S)2.CO, by the action of aluminiumchloride and carbonyl chloride on thiophene.
thermogen: Caloric; heat; regarded as a material but imponderablesubstance.
tyrannicidal: Of or pertaining to tyrannicide, or the murder of a tyrant.Booth.
to-beat: To beat thoroughly or severely. [Obs.] Layamon.
tingent: Having the power to tinge. [R.]As for the white part, it appears much less enriched with the tingentproperty. Boyle.
topman: A man stationed in the top.
trois point: The third point from the outer edge on each player's hometable.
tac: A kind of customary payment by a tenant; -- a word used in oldrecords. Cowell. Burrill.
tye: A chain or rope, one end of which passes through the mast, andis made fast to the center of a yard; the other end is attached to atackle, by means of which the yard is hoisted or lowered.
tuberous: Consisting of, or bearing, tubers; resembling a tuber.-- Tu"ber*ous*ness, n.
thible: A slice; a skimmer; a spatula; a pudding stick. [Obs. or Prov.Eng.] Ainsworth.
tardo: Slow; -- a direction to perform a passage slowly.
tredille: A game at cards for three.
tachyglossa: A division of monotremes which comprises the spiny ant-eatersof Australia and New Guinea. See Illust. under Echidna.
tapiser: A maker of tapestry; an upholsterer. [R.] Chaucer.
thorite: A mineral of a brown to black color, or, as in the varietyorangite, orange-yellow. It is essentially a silicate of thorium.
tenebrificous: Tenebrific.Authors who are tenebrificous stars. Addison.
torch: A light or luminary formed of some combustible substance, as ofresinous wood; a large candle or flambeau, or a lamp giving a large,flaring flame.They light the nuptial torch. Milton.Torch thistle. (Bot.) See under Thistle.
turacin: A red or crimson pigment obtained from certain feathers ofseveral species of turacou; whence the name. It contains nearly sixper cent of copper.
tablespoonful: As much as a tablespoon will hold; enough to fill a tablespoon.It is usually reckoned as one half of a fluid ounce, or four fluiddrams.
turbinite: A petrified shell resembling the genus Turbo. [R.]
tendrac: Any one of several species of small insectivores of the familyCentetidæ, belonging to Ericulus, Echinope, and related genera,native of Madagascar. They are more or less spinose and resemble thehedgehog in habits. The rice tendrac (Oryzorictes hora) is veryinjurious to rice crops. Some of the species are called also tenrec.
tellurian: Of or pertaining to the earth. De Quincey.
trunk engine: An engine having a trunk piston, as most internal combustionengines.
titanic: Of or relating to Titans, or fabled giants of ancientmythology; hence, enormous in size or strength; as, Titanicstructures.
taeniola: One of the radial partitions which separate the internalcavities of certain medusæ.
telluric: Of or pertaining to tellurium; derived from, or resembling,tellurium; specifically, designating those compounds in which theelement has a higher valence as contrasted with tellurous compounds;as, telluric acid, which is analogous to sulphuric acid. Telluricbismuth (Min.), tetradymite.-- Telluric silver (Min.), hessite.
telemotor: A hydraulic device by which the movement of the wheel on thebridge operates the steering gear at the stern.
tlinkit: The Indians of a seafaring group of tribes of southern Alaskacomprising the Koluschan stock. Previous to deterioration fromcontact with the whites they were the foremost traders of thenorthwest. They built substantial houses of cedar adorned with  totempoles, and were expert stone carvers and copper workers. Slavery, thepotlatch, and the use of immense labrets were characteristic. Manynow work in the salmon industry.
transferography: The act or process of copying inscriptions, or the like, bymaking transfers.
taeniata: A division of Ctenophora including those which have a long,ribbonlike body. The Venus's girdle is the most familiar example.
trigamous: Having three sorts of flowers in the same head, -- male,female, and hermaphrodite, or perfect, flowers.
thecla: Any one of many species of small delicately colored butterfliesbelonging to Thecla and allied genera; -- called also hairstreak, andelfin.
threnody: A song of lamentation; a threnode. Sir T. Herbert.
turntable: A large revolving platform, for turning railroad cars,locomotives, etc., in a different direction; -- called alsoturnplate.
tectology: A division of morphology created by Haeckel; the science oforganic individuality constituting the purely structural portion ofmorphology, in which the organism is regarded as composed of organicindividuals of different orders, each organ being considered anindividual. See Promorphology, and Morphon.
technicals: Those things which pertain to the practical part of an art,science, or profession; technical terms; technics.
trojan: Of or pertaining to ancient Troy or its inhabitants.-- n.
textually: In a textual manner; in the text or body of a work; inaccordance with the text.
tigress: The female of the tiger. Holland.
tetragonal: Of or pertaining to a tetragon; having four angles or sides;thus, the square, the parallelogram, the rhombus, and the trapeziumare tetragonal fingers.
tyran: A tyrant. [Obs.]Lordly love is such a tyran fell. Spenser.
trinitrocellulose: Gun cotton; -- so called because regarded as containing threenitro groups.
tepefy: To make or become tepid, or moderately warm. Goldsmith.
t connection: The connection of two coils diagrammatically as a letter T,chiefly used as a connection for passing transformers. When the threefree ends are connected to a source of three-phase current, two-phasecurrent may be derived from the secondary circuits. The reversearrangement may be used to transform from two-phase. -- T"-connected,a.
thermotank: A tank containing pipes through which circulates steam, water,air, or the like, for heating or cooling; -- used in some heating andventilation systems.
tumblerful: As much as a tumbler will hold; enough to fill a tumbler.
tablement: A table. [Obs.]Tablements and chapters of pillars. Holland.
tutrix: A female guardian; a tutoress. [R.] Smollett.
throb: To beat, or pulsate, with more than usual force or rapidity; tobeat in consequence of agitation; to palpitate; -- said of the heart,pulse, etc.My heart Throbs to know one thing. Shak.Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast. Shak.
thialol: A colorless oily liquid, (C2H5)2S2, having a strong garlicodor; -- called also ethyl disulphide. By extension, any one of theseries of related compounds.
trinitarian: Of or pertaining to the Trinity, the doctrine of the Trinity,or believers in that doctrine.
triple-tail: An edible fish (Lobotes Surinamensis) found in the warmer partsof all the oceans, and common on the southern and middle coasts ofthe United States. When living it is silvery gray, and becomes brownor blackish when dead. Its dorsal and anal fins are long, and extendback on each side of the tail. It has large silvery scales which areused in the manufacture of fancy work. Called also, locally, blackperch, grouper, and flasher.
toboggan: A kind of sledge made of pliable board, turned up at one orboth ends, used for coasting down hills or prepared inclined planes;also, a sleigh or sledge, to be drawn by dogs, or by hand, over softand deep snow. [Written also tobogan, and tarbogan.]
tomb: To place in a tomb; to bury; to inter; to entomb.I tombed my brother that I might be blessed. Chapman.
thus: The commoner kind of frankincense, or that obtained from theNorway spruce, the long-leaved pine, and other conifers.
tilery: A place where tiles are made or burned; a tile kiln.
trichroism: The quality possessed by some crystals of presenting differentcolors in three different directions.
tempera: A mode or process of painting; distemper.
talbot: A sort of dog, noted for quick scent and eager pursuit of game.[Obs.] Wase (1654).
trace: One of two straps, chains, or ropes of a harness, extendingfrom the collar or breastplate to a whiffletree attached to a vehicleor thing to be drawn; a tug.
thirtieth: The quotient of a unit divided by thirty; one of thirty equalparts.
tuscan: Of or pertaining to Tuscany in Italy; -- specificallydesignating one of the five orders of architecture recognized anddescribed by the Italian writers of the 16th century, orcharacteristic of the order. The original of this order was not usedby the Greeks, but by the Romans under the Empire. See Order, andIllust. of Capital.
telegraph plant: An East Indian tick trefoil (Meibomia gyrans), whose lateralleaflets jerk up and down like the arms of a semaphore, and alsorotate on their axes.
two-cleft: Divided about half way from the border to the base into twosegments; bifid.
tongued: Having a tongue.Tongued like the night crow. Donne.
tamandu: A small ant-eater (Tamandua tetradactyla) native of thetropical parts of South America.
trig: To fill; to stuff; to cram. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
tigh: A close, or inclosure; a croft. [Obs.] Cowell.
transpicuous: Transparent; pervious to the sight. [R.] "The wide,transpicuous air." Milton.
tetrodon: Any one of numerous species of plectognath fishes belonging toTetrodon and allied genera. Each jaw is furnished with two large,thick, beaklike, bony teeth. [Written also tetradon.]
torril: A worthless woman; also, a worthless horse. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
three: One more than two; two and one. "I offer thee three things." 2Sam. xxiv. 12.Three solemn aisles approach the shrine. Keble.
terpsichore: The Muse who presided over the choral song and the dance,especially the latter.
traducianism: The doctrine that human souls are produced by the act ofgeneration; -- opposed to creationism, and infusionism.
touchable: Capable of being touched; tangible.-- Touch"a*ble*ness, n.
telechirograph: An instrument for  telegraphically transmitting and receivinghandwritten messages, as photographically by a beam of light from amirror.
tranquilness: Quality or state of being tranquil.
thriftless: Without thrift; not prudent or prosperous in money affairs.-- Thrift"less*ly, adv.-- Thrift"less*ness, n.
twisting: a. & n. from Twist. Twisting pair. (Kinematics) See under Pair,n., 7.
trematode: One of the Trematodea. Also used adjectively.
titrate: To analyse, or determine the strength of, by means of standardsolutions. Cf. Standardized solution, under Solution.
transition zone: The zone lying between the Boreal and Sonoran zones of NorthAmerica. It includes an eastern or humid subdivision and a westernarid one of corresponding temperature comprising the northern GreatPlains and the lower slopes of the mountains of the western UnitedStates and Mexico. Called also Neutral zone.
triangularly: In a triangular manner; in the form of a triangle. Dampier.
textuist: A textualist; a textman. [Obs.]The crabbed textualists of his time. Milton.
tilestone: A kind of laminated shale or sandstone belonging to some of thelayers of the Upper Silurian.
tahitian: Of or pertaining to Tahiti, an island in the Pacific Ocean.-- n.
tomboy: A romping girl; a hoiden. [Colloq.] J. Fletcher.
truancy: The act of playing truant, or the state of being truant; as,addicted to truancy.
temporo-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the temple, or temporal bone; as, temporofacial.
trachyte: An igneous rock,usually light gray in color and breaking with arough surface. It consists chiefly of orthoclase feldspar withsometimes hornblende and mica.
teocalli: Literally, God's house; a temple, usually of pyramidal form,such as were built by the aborigines of Mexico, Yucatan, etc.And Aztec priests upon their teocallis Beat the wild war-drums madeof serpent's skin. Longfellow.
topsoiling: The act or art of taking off the top soil of land before anexcavation or embankment is begun.
theatric: Theatrical.Woods over woods in gay, theatric pride. Goldsmith.
thermotype: A picture (as of a slice of wood) obtained by first wetting theobject slightly with hydrochloric or dilute sulphuric acid, thentaking an impression with a press, and next strongly heating thisimpression.
thimbleful: As much as a thimble will hold; a very small quantity.For a thimbleful of golf, a thimbleful of love. Dryden.
typolithography: A branch of lithography in which impressions from printers'types are transferred to stone for reproduction. --Ty`po*lith`o*graph"ic (#), a.
typesetter: One who, or that which, sets type; a compositor; a machine forsetting type.
thursday: The fifth day of the week, following Wednesday and precedingFriday. Holy Thursday. See under Holy.
tibia: The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the twobones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
thorow: Through. [Obs.] "Thorow bramble, pits, and floods." Beau. & Fl.
turpeth: The root of Ipomoea Turpethum, a plant of Ceylon, Malabar, andAustralia, formerly used in medicine as a purgative; -- sometimescalled vegetable turpeth.
traps: Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods;luggage; things. [Colloq.]
turtledove: Any one of numerous species of pigeons belonging to Turtur andallied genera, native of various parts of the Old World; especially,the common European species (Turtur vulgaris), which is noted for itsplaintive note, affectionate disposition, and devotion to its mate.
transformation: The act of transforming, or the state of being transformed;change of form or condition. Specifically: --(a) (Biol.)
two-hand: Employing two hangs; as, the two-hand alphabet. SeeDactylology.
tangibility: The quality or state of being tangible.
thwack: A heavy blow with something flat or heavy; a thump.With many a stiff thwack, many a bang, Hard crab tree and old ironrang. Hudibras.
tensibility: The quality or state of being tensible; tensility.
try: To examine or investigate judicially; to examine by witnessesor other judicial evidence and the principles of law; as, to try acause, or a criminal.
to-break: To break completely; to break in pieces. [Obs.]With nose and mouth to-broke. Chaucer.
trespasser: One who commits a trespass; as:(a) (Law) One who enters upon another's land, or violates his rights.(b) A transgressor of the moral law; an offender; a sinner.
tartrated: Containing, or derived from, tartar; combined with tartaricacid.
trophonian: Of or pertaining to Trophonius, his architecture, or his caveand oracle.
tuyere: A nozzle, mouthpiece, or fixture through which the blast isdelivered to the interior of a blast furnace, or to the fire of aforge. [Corruptly written also tweer, and twier.] Tuyère arch, theembrasure, in the wall of a blast furnace through which the tuyèreenters.
trainable: Capable of being trained or educated; as, boys trainable tovirtue. Richardson.
thine: A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou, nowsuperseded in common discourse by your, the possessive of you, butmaintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usuallanguage of the Friends, or Quakers.
trabea: A toga of purple, or ornamented with purple horizontal stripes.-- worn by kings, consuls, and augurs. Dr. W. Smith.
thunderbird: An Australian insectivorous singing bird (Pachycephalagutturalis). The male is conspicuously marked with black and yellow,and has a black crescent on the breast. Called also white-throatedthickhead, orange-breasted thrust, black-crowned thrush, gutturalthrush, and black-breasted flycatcher.
true-born: Of genuine birth; having a right by birth to any title; as, atrue-born Englishman.
triplite: A mineral of a dark brown color, generally with a fibrous,massive structure. It is a fluophosphate of iron and manganese.
tusked: Furnished with tusks.The tusked boar out of the wood. Milton.
transanimation: The conveyance of a soul from one body to another. [R.] Fuller.
technologist: One skilled in technology; one who treats of arts, or of theterms of arts.
trimurti: The triad, or trinity, of Hindoo gods, consisting of Brahma,the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer. [Spelledalso Trimurtti.]
torturous: Involving, or pertaining to, torture. [R.] "The torturouscrucifixion." I. Disraeli.
touchiness: The quality or state of being touchy peevishness; irritability;irascibility.
thriftiness: The quality or state of being thrifty; thrift.
trochometer: A contrivance for computing the revolutions of a wheel; anodometer.
tactable: Capable of being touched; tangible. [R.] "They [women] beingcreated to be both tractable and tactable." Massinger.
toluid: A complex double tolyl and toluidine derivative of glycocoll,obtained as a white crystalline substance.
though: Granting, admitting, or supposing that; notwithstanding that;if.Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him. Job xiii. 15.Not that I so affirm, though so it seem. Milton.
tailrace: The channel in which tailings, suspended in water, areconducted away.
tatt: To make (anything) by tatting; to work at tatting; as, tattededging.
trimembral: Having, or consisting of, three members.
traductive: Capable of being deduced; derivable. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
topsoil: The upper layer of soil; surface soil.
time signature: A sign at the beginning of a composition or movement, placedafter the key signature, to indicate its time or meter. Also calledrhythmical signature.
