It is in the form of a fraction, of which thedenominator indicates the kind of note taken as time unit for thebeat, and the numerator, the number of these to the measure.
tangelo: A hybrid between the tangerine orange and the grapefruit, orpomelo; also, the fruit.
townlet: A small town. North Brit. Rev.
taglia: A peculiar combination of pulleys. Brande & C.
tracheata: An extensive division of arthropods comprising all those whichbreathe by tracheæ, as distinguished from Crustacea, which breathe bymeans of branchiæ.
twifallow: To plow, or fallow, a second time (land that has been oncefallowed).
thermoregulator: A device for the automatic regulation of temperature; athermostat.
tear: A drop of the limpid, saline fluid secreted, normally in smallamount, by the lachrymal gland, and diffused between the eye and theeyelids to moisten the parts and facilitate their motion. Ordinarilythe secretion passes through the lachrymal duct into the nose, butwhen it is increased by emotion or other causes, it overflows thelids.And yet for thee ne wept she never a tear. Chaucer.
trapball: An old game of ball played with a trap. See 4th Trap, 4.
tachydidaxy: A short or rapid method of instructing. [R.]
tumultuation: Irregular or disorderly movement; commotion; as, thetumultuation of the parts of a fluid. [Obs.] Boyle.
tain: Thin tin plate; also, tin foil for mirrors. Knight.
taxability: The quality or state of being taxable; taxableness.
thyro-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the thyroid body or the thyroid cartilage; as,thyrohyal.
throaty: Guttural; hoarse; having a guttural voice. "Hard, throatywords." Howell.
tragedienne: A woman who plays in tragedy.
thermoelectrometer: An instrument for measuring the strength of an electric currentin the heat which it produces, or for determining the heat developedby such a current.
tympanites: A flatulent distention of the belly; tympany.
turret steamer: A whaleback steamer with a hatch coaming, usually about sevenfeet high, extending almost continuously fore and aft.
tropism: Modification of the direction of growth.
tarn: A mountain lake or pool.A lofty precipice in front, A silent tarn below. Wordsworth.
trying: Adapted to try, or put to severe trial; severe; afflictive; as,a trying occasion or position.
thalamencephalon: The segment of the brain next in front of the midbrain,including the thalami, pineal gland, and pituitary body; thediencephalon; the interbrain.
torsibillty: The tendency, as of a rope, to untwist after being twisted.
theorist: One who forms theories; one given to theory and speculation; aspeculatist. Cowper.The greatest theoretists have given the preference to such agovernment as that which obtains in this kingdom. Addison.
tremble: An involuntary shaking or quivering.I am all of a tremble when I think of it. W. Black.
trimethylene: A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H6, isomeric with propylene andobtained from it indirectly. It is the base of a series of compoundsanalogous to the aromatic hydrocarbons.
tetrazo-: A combining form (also used adjectively), designating any oneof a series of double derivatives of the azo and diazo compoundscontaining four atoms of nitrogen.
taxonomic: Pertaining to, or involving, taxonomy, or the laws andprinciples of classification; classificatory.
transcendentality: The quality or state of being transcendental.
treasure: To collect and deposit, as money or other valuable things, forfuture use; to lay up; to hoard; usually with up; as, to treasure upgold.
toxodonta: An extinct order of Mammalia found in the South AmericanTertiary formation. The incisor teeth were long and curved andprovided with a persistent pulp. They are supposed to be related bothto the rodents and ungulates. Called also Toxodontia.
twin: Double; consisting of two similar and corresponding parts.
tenth: The interval between any tone and the tone represented on thetenth degree of the staff above it, as between one of the scale andthree of the octave above; the octave of the third.
taskwork: Work done as a task; also, work done by the job; piecework.
terneplate: Thin iron sheets coated with an alloy of lead and tin; -- socalled because made up of three metals.
trogon: Any one of numerous species of beautiful tropical birdsbelonging to the family Trogonidæ. They are noted for the brilliantcolors and the resplendent luster of their plumage.
trachytic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, trachyte.
theopathy: Capacity for religious affections or worship.
ted: To spread, or turn from the swath, and scatter for drying, asnew-mowed grass; -- chiefly used in the past participle.The smell of grain or tedded grass. Milton.The tedded hay and corn sheaved in one field. Coleridge.
top-proud: Proud to the highest degree. [R.] "This top-proud fellow."Shak.
termination: The ending of a word; a final syllable or letter; the partadded to a stem in inflection.
tinkle: To cause to clonk, or make small, sharp, quick sounds.
thanksgiver: One who gives thanks, or acknowledges a kindness. Barrow.
trustiness: The quality or state of being trusty.
title: The panel for the name, between the bands of the back of abook.
tormentry: Anything producing torment, annoyance, or pain. [Obs.] Chaucer.
tableman: A man at draughts; a piece used in playing games at tables. SeeTable, n., 10. [R.] Bacon.
toxoid: An altered form of a toxin, possessing little or no toxicpower.
tethys: A genus of a large naked mollusks having a very large, broad,fringed cephalic disk, and branched dorsal gills. Some of the speciesbecome a foot long and are brilliantly colored.
tricksy: Exhibiting artfulness; trickish. "My tricksy spirit!" Shak.he tricksy policy which in the seventeenth century passed for statewisdom. Coleridge.
transvertible: Capable of being transverted. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
tensive: Giving the sensation of tension, stiffness, or contraction.A tensive pain from distension of the parts. Floyer.
triton: A fabled sea demigod, the son of Neptune and Amphitrite, andthe trumpeter of Neptune. He is represented by poets and painters ashaving the upper part of his body like that of a man, and the lowerpart like that of a fish. He often has a trumpet made of a shell.Have sight of Proteus rising from the sea, Or hear old Triton blowhis wreathed horn. Wordsworth.
tottle: To walk in a wavering, unsteady manner; to toddle; to topple.[Colloq.]
transliterate: To express or represent in the characters of another alphabet;as, to transliterate Sanskrit words by means of English letters. A.J. Ellis.
tensioned: Extended or drawn out; subjected to tension. "A highlytensioned string." Tyndall.
trinoctial: Lasting during three nights; comprising three nights.
tapestry beetle: A small black dermestoid beetle (Attagenus piceus) whose larvafeeds on tapestry, carpets, silk, fur, flour, and various othergoods.
tropine: A white crystalline alkaloid, C8H15NO, produced by decomposingatropine.
tromp: A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part ofa vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, iscarried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it isled to a furnace. [Written also trompe, and trombe.]
towline: A line used to tow vessels; a towrope.
tith: Tight; nimble. [Obs.]Of a good stirring strain too, she goes tith. Beau. & Fl.
tasto: A key or thing touched to produce a tone. Tasto solo, singletouch; -- in old music, a direction denoting that the notes in thebass over or under which it is written should be performed alone, orwith no other chords than unisons and octaves.
teem: To pour, as steel, from a melting pot; to fill, as a mold, withmolten metal.
tuberculin: A fluid containing the products formed by the growth of thetubercle bacillus in a suitable culture medium.
triennial: Something which takes place or appears once in three years.
thermotypy: The art or process of obtaining thermotypes.
transmissible: Capable of being transmitted from one to another; capable ofbeing passed through any body or substance.
tideland: Land that is overflowed by tide water; hence, land near thesea.
tubulidentate: Having teeth traversed by canals; -- said of certain edentates.
tralucency: Translucency; as, the tralucency of a gem. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
thallium: A rare metallic element of the aluminium group found in someminerals, as certain pyrites, and also in the lead-chamber deposit inthe manufacture of sulphuric acid. It is isolated as a heavy, soft,bluish white metal, easily oxidized in moist air, but preserved bykeeping under water. Symbol Tl. Atomic weight 203.7.
tittle: A particle; a minute part; a jot; an iota.It is easier for heaven and earth to pass, than one tittle of the lawto fail. Luke xvi. 17.Every tittle of this prophecy is most exactly verified. South.
toxicant: A poisonous agent or drug, as opium; an intoxicant.
testamental: Of or pertaining to a testament; testamentary.Thy testamental cup I take, And thus remember thee. J. Montgomery.
tautologous: Repeating the same thing in different words; tautological. [R.]Tooke.
torchon paper: Paper with a rough surface; esp., handmade paper of greathardness for the use of painters in water colors.
thumper: One who, or that which, thumps.
try cock: A cock for withdrawing a small quantity of liquid, as fortesting.
theophany: A manifestation of God to man by actual appearance, usually asan incarnation.
tinder: Something very inflammable, used for kindling fire from aspark, as scorched linen. German tinder. Same as Amadou.-- Tinder box, a box in which tinder is kept.
thinner: One who thins, or makes thinner.
totty: Unsteady; dizzy; tottery. [Obs.or Prov. Eng.] Sir W. Scott.For yet his noule [head] was totty of the must. Spenser.
thirteenth: The interval comprising an octave and a sixth.
thill: The floor of a coal mine. Raymond. Thill coupling, a device forconnecting the thill of a vehicle to the axle.
transgression: The act of transgressing, or of passing over or beyond any law,civil or moral; the violation of a law or known principle ofrectitude; breach of command; fault; offense; crime; sin.Forgive thy people . . . all their transgressions wherein they havetransgressed against thee. I Kings viii. 50.What rests, but that the mortal sentence pass On his transgression,death denounced that day Milton.The transgression is in the stealer. Shak.
tomium: The cutting edge of the bill of a bird.
tudor: Of or pertaining to a royal line of England, descended fromOwen Tudor of Wales, who married the widowed queen of Henry V. Thefirst reigning Tudor was Henry VII.; the last, Elizabeth. Tudor style(Arch.), the latest development of Gothic architecture in England,under the Tudors, characterized by flat four-centered arches, shallowmoldings, and a profusion of paneling on the walls.
top-dress: To apply a surface dressing of manureto,as land.
tinny: Pertaining to, abounding with, or resembling, tin. "The tinnystrand." Drayton.
tillable: Capable of being tilled; fit for the plow; arable.
trimestrial: Of or pertaining to a trimester, or period of three months;occurring once in every three months; quarterly.
tuneful: Harmonious; melodious; musical; as, tuneful notes. " Tunefulbirds." Milton.-- Tune"ful*ly, adv.-- Tune"ful*ness, n.
trithing: One of three ancient divisions of a county in England; -- nowcalled riding. [Written also riding.] Blackstone.
thickhead: Any one of several species of Australian singing birds of thegenus Pachycephala. The males of some of the species are bright-colored. Some of the species are popularly called thrushes.
troublesome: Giving trouble or anxiety; vexatious; burdensome; wearisome.This troublesome world. Book of Common Prayer.These troublesome disguises that we wear. Milton.My mother will never be troublesome to me. Pope.
theorize: To form a theory or theories; to form opinions solely bytheory; to speculate.
toftman: The owner of a toft. See Toft, 3.
true-blue: Of inflexible honesty and fidelity; -- a term derived from thetrue, or Coventry, blue, formerly celebrated for its unchangingcolor. See True blue, under Blue.
tetrarchy: The district under a Roman tetrarch; the office or jurisdictionof a tetrarch; a tetrarchate.
twelvescore: Twelve times twenty; two hundred and forty.
tanistry: In Ireland, a tenure of family lands by which the proprietorhad only a life estate, to which he was admitted by election.
touch: To be tangent to. See Tangent, a.
tumbler: A piece attached to, or forming part of, the hammer of agunlock, upon which the mainspring acts and in which are the notchesfor sear point to enter.
threat: The expression of an intention to inflict evil or injury onanother; the declaration of an evil, loss, or pain to come; meance;threatening; denunciation.There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats. Shak.
thirst: To have a thirst for. [R.]He seeks his keeper's flesh, and thirsts his blood. Prior.
transitional: Of or pertaining to transition; involving or denotingtransition; as, transitional changes; transitional stage.
thymate: A compound of thymol analogous to a salt; as, sodium thymate.
trusion: The act of pushing or thrusting. [R.] Bentley.
tricentenary: Including, or relating to, the interval of three hundred years;tercentenary.-- n.
tetany: A morbid condition resembling tetanus, but distinguished fromit by being less severe and having intermittent spasms.
top-dressing: The act of applying a dressing of manure to the surface ofland; also, manure so applied.
top-boots: High boots, having generally a band of some kind of light-colored leather around the upper part of the leg; riding boots.
thesmothete: A lawgiver; a legislator; one of the six junior archons atAthens.
transliteration: The act or product of transliterating, or of expressing wordsof a language by means of the characters of another alphabet.
teufit: The lapwing; -- called also teuchit. [Prov. Eng.]
tanglefish: The sea adder, or great pipefish of Europe.
temulentive: Somewhat temulent; addicted to drink. [R.] R. Junius.
turacou: Any one of several species of plantain eaters of the genusTuracus, native of Africa. They are remarkable for the peculiar greenand red pigments found in their feathers. [Written also touraco, andtouracou.]
truth: To assert as true; to declare. [R.]Had they [the ancients] dreamt this, they would have truthed itheaven. Ford.
toty: Totty. [Obs.]My head is totty of my swink to-night. Chaucer.
townhall: A public hall or building, belonging to a town, where thepublic offices are established, the town council meets, the peopleassemble in town meeting, etc.
triple: To make threefold, or thrice as much or as many; to treble; as,to triple the tax on coffee.
tablebook: A tablet; a notebook.Put into your tablebook whatever you judge worthly. Dryden.
terre-verte: An olive-green earth used as a pigment. See Glauconite.
treasurer: One who has the care of a treasure or treasure or treasury; anofficer who receives the public money arising from taxes and duties,or other sources of revenue, takes charge of the same, and disbursesit upon orders made by the proper authority; one who has charge ofcollected funds; as, the treasurer of a society or corporation. Lordhigh treasurer of England, formerly, the third great officer of thecrown. His office is now executed by five persons styled the lordscommissioners of the treasury, or treasury lords.
tile-drain: To drain by means of tiles; to furnish with a tile drain.
tomjohn: A kind of open sedan used in Ceylon, carried by a single poleon men's shoulders.
tetanin: A poisonous base (ptomaine) formed in meat broth through theagency of a peculiar microbe from the wound of a person who has diedof tetanus; -- so called because it produces tetanus as one of itsprominent effects.
thy: Of thee, or belonging to thee; the more common form of thine,possessive case of thou; -- used always attributively, and chiefly inthe solemn or grave style, and in poetry. Thine is used in thepredicate; as, the knife is thine. See Thine.Our father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdomcome. Thy will be done. Matt. vi. 9,10.These are thy glorious works, Parent of good. Milton.
turtler: One who catches turtles or tortoises. "The Jamaica turtlers."Dampier.
theban: Of or pertaining to Thebes. Theban year (Anc. Chron.), theEgyptian year of 365 days and 6 hours. J. Bryant.
tranquillity: The quality or state of being tranquil; calmness; composure.
triandria: A Linnæan class of plants having three distinct and equalstamens.
tetrapod: An insect characterized by having but four perfect legs, ascertain of the butterflies.
thitherward: To ward that place; in that direction.They shall ask the way to Zion, with their faces thitherward. Jer. l.5.
tropologize: To use in a tropological sense, as a word; to make a trope of.[R.]If . . . Minerva be tropologized into prudence. Cudworth.
tolyl: The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristicof certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as,tolyl carbinol.
thermal: Of or pertaining to heat; warm; hot; as, the thermal unit;thermal waters.The thermal condition of the earth. J. D. Forbes.Thermal conductivity, Thermal spectrum. See under Conductivity, andSpectrum.-- Thermal unit (Physics), a unit chosen for the comparison orcalculation of quantities of heat. The unit most commonly employed isthe amount of heat necessary to raise the temperature of one gram orone pound of water from zero to one degree Centigrade. See Calorie,and under Unit.
tractor: Two small, pointed rods of metal, formerly used in thetreatment called Perkinism.
trepan: A crown-saw or cylindrical saw for perforating the skull,turned, when used, like a bit or gimlet. See Trephine.
tubuliform: Having the form of a small tube.
typothetae: Printers; -- used in the name of an association of the masterprinters of the United States and Canada, called The United Typothetæof America.
threap: To contend obstinately; to be pertinacious. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.]It's not for a man with a woman to threap. Percy's Reliques.
thousandth: The quotient of a unit divided by a thousand; one of a thousandequal parts into which a unit is divided.
truck: A swiveling carriage, consisting of a frame with one or morepairs of wheels and the necessary boxes, springs, etc., to carry andguide one end of a locomotive or a car; -- sometimes called bogie inEngland. Trucks usually have four or six wheels.
teetotum: A child's toy, somewhat resembling a top, and twirled by thefingers.The staggerings of the gentleman . . . were like those of a teetotumnearly spent. Dickens.
tranation: The act of swimming over. [Obs.] Bailey.
transmarine: Lying or being beyond the sea. Howell.
taste: The one of the five senses by which certain properties ofbodies (called their taste, savor, flavor) are ascertained by contactwith the organs of taste.
transmigrant: Migrating or passing from one place or state to another;passing from one residence to another.-- n.
thionyl: The hypothetical radical SO, regarded as an essentialconstituent of certain sulphurous compounds; as, thionyl chloride.
trade-mark: A peculiar distinguishing mark or device affixed by amanufacturer or a merchant to his goods, the exclusive right of usingwhich is recognized by law.
threnode: A threne, or threnody; a dirge; a funeral song.
turpitude: Inherent baseness or vileness of principle, words, or actions;shameful wickedness; depravity. Shak.
telling: Operating with great effect; effective; as, a telling speech.-- Tell"ing*ly, adv.
ting: A sharp sound, as of a bell; a tinkling.
trunked: Having (such) a trunk.Thickset with strong and well-trunked trees. Howell.
trickish: Given to tricks; artful in making bargains; given to deceptionand cheating; knavish.-- Trick"ish*ly, adv.-- Trick"ish*ness, n.
tripitaka: The three divisions, or "baskets" (pitakas), of buddhistscriptures, -- the Vinayapitaka [Skr. Vinayapitsaka] , or Basket ofDiscipline; Suttapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Discourses; andAbhidhammapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Metaphysics.
torridness: The quality or state of being torrid or parched.
twaite: A European shad; -- called also twaite shad. See Shad.
testing: The operation of refining gold or silver in a test, or cupel;cupellation. Testing machine (Engin.), a machine used in thedetermination of the strength of materials, as iron, stone, etc., andtheir behavior under strains of various kinds, as elongation,bending, crushing, etc.
teaspoon: A small spoon used in stirring and sipping tea, coffee, etc.,and for other purposes.
tullian: Belonging to, or in the style of, Tully (Marcus TulliusCicero).
tentaculocyst: One of the auditory organs of certain medusæ; -- called alsoauditory tentacle.
trespass: To commit a trespass; esp., to enter unlawfully upon the landof another.
telegrammic: Pertaining to, or resembling, a telegram; laconic; concise;brief. [R.]
tendril: A slender, leafless portion of a plant by which it becomesattached to a supporting body, after which the tendril usuallycontracts by coiling spirally.
theologize: To render theological; to apply to divinity; to reduce to asystem of theology.School divinity was but Aristotle's philosophy theologized. Glanvill.
triangulares: The triangular, or maioid, crabs. See Illust. under Maioid, andIllust. of Spider crab, under Spider.
thermobarometer: An instrument for determining altitudes by the boiling point ofwater.
tumpline: A strap placed across a man's forehead to assist him incarrying a pack on his back. [Local, U. S.] Bartlett.
trigamy: The act of marrying, or the state of being married, threetimes; also, the offense of having three husbands or three wives atthe same time.
touchstone: Lydian stone; basanite; -- so called because used to test thepurity of gold and silver by the streak which is left upon the stonewhen it is rubbed by the metal. See Basanite.
terrorize: To impress with terror; to coerce by intimidation.Humiliated by the tyranny of foreign despotism, and terrorized byecclesiastical authority. J. A. Symonds.
teache: One of the series of boilers in which the cane juice is treatedin making sugar; especially, the last boiler of the series. Ure.
try-square: An instrument used by carpenters, joiners, etc., for laying offright angles off right angles, and testing whether work is square.
tuille: In plate armor, a suspended plate in from of the thigh. SeeIllust. of Tasses.
tramming: The act or process of forming trams. See 2d Tram.
tile: To protect from the intrusion of the uninitiated; as, to tile aMasonic lodge.
trial balance: The testing of a ledger to discover whether the debits andcredits balance, by finding whether the sum of the personal creditsincreased by the difference between the debit and credit sums in themerchandise and other impersonal accounts equals the sum of personaldebits. The equality would not show that the items were all correctlyposted.
tollgate: A gate where toll is taken.
treacle: A remedy against poison. See Theriac, 1.We kill the viper, and make treacle of him. Jer. Taylor.
tellership: The office or employment of a teller.
torpescence: The quality or state or being torpescent; torpidness; numbness;stupidity.
traffic mile: Any unit of the total obtained by adding the passenger milesand ton miles in a railroad's transportation for a given period; -- aterm and practice of restricted or erroneous usage.
tipping: A distinct articulation given in playing quick notes on theflute, by striking the tongue against the roof of the mouth; double-tonguing.
tiver: A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England inmarking sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
trappist: A monk belonging to a branch of the Cistercian Order, which wasestablished by Armand de Rancé in 1660 at the monastery of La Trappein Normandy. Extreme austerity characterizes their discipline. Theywere introduced permanently into the United States in 1848, and havemonasteries in Iowa and Kentucky.
trituberculy: A theory of the development of mammalian molar teeth. Theprimitive stage is that of simple cones, as in reptiles. The simplecone then developed a smaller cone in front and another behind. Next,a cingulum was developed, and the three cones became arranged in atriangle, the two smaller cusps having moved to the outer side inupper and to the inner in lower molars. This primitive triangle iscalled the trigon or trigonid and this stage the tritubercular ortrigonodont. The trigon being a cutting apparatus, an extension ofthe posterior part of the crown was developed in lower molars forcrushing, and a smaller corresponding part appeared in upper molars.Another large cone then arose, usually from the cingulum. In morecomplex forms, smaller intermediate cusps appeared.
to-name: A name added, for the sake of distinction, to one's surname, orused instead of it. [Scot.] Jamieson.
transexion: Change of sex. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
thumbkin: An instrument of torture for compressing the thumb; athumbscrew.
thereof: Of that or this.In the day that thou eatest thereof, thou shalt surely die. Gen. ii.17.
top-chain: A chain for slinging the lower yards, in time of action, toprevent their falling, if the ropes by which they are hung are shotaway.
truncheon: To beat with a truncheon. Shak.
triphylite: A mineral of a grayish-green or bluish color, consisting of thephosphates of iron, manganese, and lithia.
tripersonality: The state of existing as three persons in one Godhead; trinity.
theophilosophic: Combining theism and philosophy, or pertaining to thecombination of theism and philosophy.
theretofore: Up to that time; before then; -- correlative with heretofore.
topmast: The second mast, or that which is next above the lower mast,and below the topgallant mast.
thermotonus: A condition of tonicity with respect to temperature.
taproot: The root of a plant which penetrates the earth directlydownward to a considerable depth without dividing.
tapeworm: Any one of numerous species of cestode worms belonging to Tæniaand many allied genera. The body is long, flat, and composed ofnumerous segments or proglottids varying in shape, those toward theend of the body being much larger and longer than the anterior ones,and containing the fully developed sexual organs. The head is small,destitute of a mouth, but furnished with two or more suckers (whichvary greatly in shape in different genera), and sometimes, also, withhooks for adhesion to the walls of the intestines of the animals inwhich they are parasitic. The larvæ (see Cysticercus) live in theflesh of various creatures, and when swallowed by another animal ofthe right species develop into the mature tapeworm in its intestine.See Illustration in Appendix.
twigsome: Full of, or abounding in, twigs; twiggy. [R.] " Twigsometrees." Dickens.
tombstone: A stone erected over a grave, to preserve the memory of thedeceased.
thirteen: One more than twelve; ten and three; as, thirteen ounces orpounds.
totear: To tear or rend in pieces. [Obs.] Chaucer.
totara: A coniferous tree (Podocarpus totara), next to the kauri themost valuable timber tree of New Zeland. Its hard reddish wood isused for furniture and building, esp. in wharves, bridges, etc. Alsomahogany pine.
trinucleus: A genus of Lower Silurian trilobites in which the glabella andcheeks form three rounded elevations on the head.
tum-tum: A dish made in the West Indies by beating boiled plantain quitesoft in a wooden mortar.
triceps: A muscle having three heads; specif., the great extensor of theforearm, arising by three heads and inserted into the olecranon atthe elbow.
tether: A long rope or chain by which an animal is fastened, as to astake, so that it can range or feed only within certain limits.
trinkle: To act secretly, or in an underhand way; to tamper. [Obs.]Wright.
tomaley: The liver of the lobster, which becomes green when boiled; --called also tomalline.
truant: One who stays away from business or any duty; especially, onewho stays out of school without leave; an idler; a loiterer; a shirk.Dryden.I have a truant been to chivalry. Shak.To play truant, to stray away; to loiter; especially, to stay out ofschool without leave. Sir T. Browne
trachytoid: Resembling trachyte; -- used to define the structure of certainrocks.
tinselly: Like tinsel; gaudy; showy, but cheap.
trode: imp. of Tread.On burnished hooves his war-horse trode. Tennyson.
trochanteric: Of or pertaining to one or both of the trochanters.
transcursion: A rambling or ramble; a passage over bounds; an excursion.[Obs.] Howell.
tonnish: In the ton; fashionable; modish.-- Ton"nish*ness, n.
tory: A member of the conservative party, as opposed to theprogressive party which was formerly called the Whig, and is nowcalled the Liberal, party; an earnest supporter of exsisting royaland ecclesiastical authority.
tabaret: A stout silk having satin stripes, -- used for furniture.
tinkerly: After the manner of a tinker. [R.]
tyro: A beginner in learning; one who is in the rudiments of anybranch of study; a person imperfectly acquainted with a subject; anovice. [Written also tiro.]The management of tyros of eighteen Is difficult. Cowper.
tableware: Ware, or articles collectively, for table use.
tagsore: Adhesion of the tail of a sheep to the wool from excoriationproduced by contact with the feces; -- called also tagbelt. [Obs.]
tollbooth: To imprison in a tollbooth. [R.]That they might tollbooth Oxford men. Bp. Corbet.
tetard: A gobioid fish (Eleotris gyrinus) of the Southern UnitedStates; -- called also sleeper.
tommy atkins: Any white regular soldier of the British army; also, suchsoldiers collectively; -- said to be fictitious name inserted in themodels given to soldiers to guide them in filling out account blanks,etc.
tartrazine: An artificial dyestuff obtained as an orange-yellow powder, andregarded as a phenyl hydrazine derivative of tartaric and sulphonicacids.
transposition: The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed.Specifically: --(a) (Alg.)
testudo: A genus of tortoises which formerly included a large number ofdiverse forms, but is now restricted to certain terrestrial species,such as the European land tortoise (Testudo Græca) and the gopher ofthe Southern United States.
tardation: The act of retarding, or delaying; retardation. [Obs.]
tartro-: A combining form (also used adjectively) used in chemistry todenote the presence of tartar or of some of its compounds orderivatives.
tosspot: A toper; one habitually given to strong drink; a drunkard.Shak.
throw-off: A start in a hunt or a race. [Eng.]
trek: The act of trekking; a drawing or a traveling; a journey; amigration. [Chiefly South Africa]
three-handed: Said of games or contests where three persons play against eachother, or two against one; as, a three-handed game of cards.
tinet: Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges. [Obs.Eng.]
turgescent: Becoming turgid or inflated; swelling; growing big.
telepolariscope: A polariscope arranged to be attached to a telescope. Lockyer.
tousle: To put into disorder; to tumble; to touse. [Colloq.]
tramontane: Lying or being beyond the mountains; coming from the other sideof the mountains; hence, foreign; barbarous.
thiosulphuric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an unstable acid, H2S2O3,analogous to sulphuric acid, and formerly called hyposulphurous acid.
turbinaceous: Of or pertaining to peat, or turf; of the nature of peat, orturf; peaty; turfy. Sir. W. Scott.
terre-tenant: One who has the actual possession of land; the occupant.[Written also ter-tenant.]
togated: Dressed in a toga or gown; wearing a gown; gowned. [R.] Sir M.Sandys.
trochili: A division of birds comprising the humming birds.
tetradic: Of or pertaining to a tetrad; possessing or having thecharacteristics of a tetrad; as, a carbon is a tetradic element.
teething: The process of the first growth of teeth, or the phenomenaattending their issue through the gums; dentition.
tethyodea: A division of Tunicata including the common attached ascidians,both simple and compound. Called also Tethioidea.
tenuirostres: An artificial group of passerine birds having slender bills, asthe humming birds.
tier: One who, or that which, ties.
tricostate: Three-ribbed; having three ribs from the base.
teest: A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.
tressured: Provided or bound with a tressure; arranged in the form of atressure.The tressured fleur-de-lis he claims To wreathe his shield. Sir W.Scott.
top-drain: To drain the surface of, as land; as, to top-drain a field orfarm.
tunguses: A group of roving Turanian tribes occupying Eastern Siberia andthe Amoor valley. They resemble the Mongols. [Written alsoTungooses.]
tunicle: A short, close-fitting vestment worn by bishops under thedalmatic, and by subdeacons.
tannin: Same as Tannic acid, under Tannic.
tack: A peculiar flavor or taint; as, a musty tack. [Obs. or Colloq.]Drayton.
thyroid: Of or pertaining to the thyroid body, thyroid cartilage, orthyroid artery; thyroideal. Thyroid cartilage. See under Larynx.-- Thyroid body, or Thyroid gland (Anat.), a glandlike but ductlessbody, or pair of bodies, of unknown function, in the floor of themouth or the region of the larynx. In man and most mammals it is ahighly vascular organ, partly surrounding the base of the larynx andthe upper part of the trachea.-- Thyroid dislocation (Surg.), dislocation of the thigh bone intothe thyroid foramen.-- Thyroid foramen, the obturator foramen.
triform: Having a triple form or character. "This triform antagonism."I. Taylor.Goddess Triform, I own thy triple spell. Lowell.
turio: A shoot or sprout from the ground. Gray.
thespian: Of or pertaining to Thespis; hence, relating to the drama;dramatic; as, the Thespian art.-- n.
tolylene: A hydrocarbon radical, C6H4.(CH2)2, regarded as characteristicof certain toluene derivatives.
theorem: A statement of a principle to be demonstrated.
terreity: Quality of being earthy; earthiness. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
tarso-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the tarsus; as, tarsometatarsus.
tumulous: Full of small hills or mounds; hilly; tumulose. [R.] Bailey.
tapered: Lighted with a taper or tapers; as, a tapered choir. [R.] T.Warton.
tola: A weight of British India. The standard tola is equal to 180grains.
twit: To vex by bringing to notice, or reminding of, a fault, defect,misfortune, or the like; to revile; to reproach; to upbraid; totaunt; as, he twitted his friend of falsehood.This these scoffers twitted the Christian with. Tillotson.Æsop minds men of their errors, without twitting them for what isamiss. L'Estrange.
tailor-made: Made by a tailor or according to a tailor's fashion; -- saidspecif. of women's garments made with certain closeness of fit,simplicity of ornament, etc.
teatish: Peevish; tettish; fretful; -- said of a child. See Tettish.[Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
trisacramentarian: One who recognizes three sacraments, and no more; -- namely,baptism, the Lord's Supper, and penance. See Sacrament.
twelfth-cake: An ornamented cake distributed among friends or visitors on thefestival of Twelfth-night.
tramrail: An overhead rail forming a track on which a trolley runs toconvey a load, as in a shop.
tete: A kind of wig; false hair.
tag-rag: The lowest class of people; the rabble. Cf. Rag, tag, andbobtail, under Bobtail.If the tag-rag people did not clap him and hiss him, I am no trueman. Shak.
testamur: A certificate of merit or proficiency; -- so called from theLatin words, Ita testamur, with which it commences.
third-penny: A third part of the profits of fines and penalties imposed atthe country court, which was among the perquisites enjoyed by theearl.
tacet: It is silent; -- a direction for a vocal or instrumental partto be silent during a whole movement.
transgressively: In a transgressive mannerAdam, perhaps, . . . from the transgressive infirmities of himself,might have erred alone. Sir T. Browne.
troll: A supernatural being, often represented as of diminutive size,but sometimes as a giant, and fabled to inhabit caves, hills, andlike places; a witch. Troll flower. (Bot.) Same as Globeflower (a).
telford: Designating, or pert. to, a road pavement having a surface ofsmall stone rolled hard and smooth, distinguished from macadam roadby its firm foundation of large stones with fragments of stone wedgedtightly, in the interstices; as, telford pavement, road, etc.
tautochronous: Occupying the same time; pertaining to, or having theproperties of, a tautochrone.
trey: Three, at cards, dice, or dominoes; a card, die, or domino ofthree spots or pips.Seven is my chance and thine is cinq and trey. Chaucer.
thallophyta: A phylum of plants of very diverse habit and structure,including the algæ, fungi, and lichens. The simpler forms, as manyblue-green algæ, yeasts, etc., are unicellular and reproducevegetatively or  by means of asexual spores; in the higher forms theplant body is a thallus, which may be filamentous or may consist ofplates of cells; it is commonly undifferentiated into stem, leaves,and roots, and shows no distinct tissue systems; the fronds of manyalgæ, however, are modified to serve many of the functions of theabove-named organs. Both asexual and sexual reproduction, often of acomplex type, occur in these forms. The Thallophyta exist almostexclusively as gametophytes, the sporophyte being absent orrudimentary. By those who do not separate the Myxophyta from theTallophyta as a distinct phylum the latter is treated as thelowermost group in the vegetable kingdom.
tetragrammaton: The mystic number four, which was often symbolized to representthe Deity, whose name was expressed by four letters among someancient nations; as, the Hebrew JeHoVaH, Greek qeo`s, Latin deus,etc.
targe: A shield or target. [Obs. or Poetic] "A buckler on a targe."Chaucer.
tricksiness: The quality or state of being tricksy; trickiness. G. Eliot.
terminist: One of a class of theologians who maintain that God has fixed acertain term for the probation of individual persons, during whichperiod, and no longer, they have the offer to grace. Murdock.
tarantulated: Bitten by a tarantula; affected with tarantism.
typhomania: A low delirium common in typhus fever.
thin: Not thickly or closely; in a seattered state; as, seed sownthin.Spain is thin sown of people. Bacon.
trowel: A tool used for smoothing a mold. Trowel bayonet. See Spadebayonet, under Spade.-- Fish trowel. See Fish slice, under Fish.
take-off: An imitation, especially in the way of caricature.
thebaine: A poisonous alkaloid, C19H21NO3, found in opium in smallquantities, having a sharp, astringent taste, and a tetanic actionresembling that of strychnine.
tetrabranchiata: An order of Cephalopoda having four gills. Among living speciesit includes only the pearly nautilus. Numerous genera and species arefound in the fossil state, such as Ammonites, Baculites, Orthoceras,etc.
triune: Being three in one; -- an epithet used to express the unity ofa trinity of persons in the Godhead.
tubipore: Any species of the genus Tubipora.
telenergy: Display of force or energy at a distance, or without contact; -- applied to mediumistic phenomena. -- Tel`en*er"gic (#), a.
therapeutist: One versed in therapeutics, or the discovery and application ofremedies.
tetanization: The production or condition of tetanus.
tavern: A public house where travelers and other transient guests areaccomodated with rooms and meals; an inn; a hotel; especially, inmodern times, a public house licensed to sell liquor in smallquantities.
tapioca: A coarsely granular substance obtained by heating, and thuspartly changing, the moistened starch obtained from the roots of thecassava. It is much used in puddings and as a thickening for soups.See Cassava.
triliteral: Consisting of three letters; trigrammic; as, a triliteral rootor word.-- n.
treenail: A long wooden pin used in fastening the planks of a vessel tothe timbers or to each other. [Written also trenail, and trunnel.]
terebene: A polymeric modification of terpene, obtained as a whitecrystalline camphorlike substance; -- called also camphene. Byextension, any one of a group of related substances.
twig: To twitch; to pull; to tweak. [Obs. or Scot.]
titulary: A person invested with a title, in virtue of which he holds anoffice or benefice, whether he performs the duties of it or not.
transflux: A flowing through, across, or beyond. [R.]
toggery: Clothes; garments; dress; as, fishing toggery. [Colloq.] togs
tamperer: One who tampers; one who deals unfairly.
tingis: A genus of small hemipterous insects which injure trees bysucking the sap from the leaves. See Illustration in Appendix.
threepence: A small silver coin of three times the value of a penny. [Eng.]
torsion: That force with which a thread, wire, or rod of any material,returns, or tends to return, to a state of rest after it has beentwisted; torsibility. Angle of torsion (of a curve) (Geom.), theindefinitely small angle between two consecutive osculating planes ofa curve of double curvature.-- Moment of torsion (Mech.) the moment of a pair of equal andopposite couples which tend to twist a body.-- Torsion balance (Physics.), an instrument for estimating veryminute forces, as electric or magnetic attractions and repulsions, bythe torsion of a very slender wire or fiber having at its lowerextremity a horizontal bar or needle, upon which the forces act.-- Torsion scale, a scale for weighing in which the fulcra of thelevers or beams are strained wires or strips acting by torsion.
top-light: A lantern or light on the top of a vessel.
thirstiness: The state of being thirsty; thirst.
tower: To rise and overtop other objects; to be lofty or very high;hence, to soar.On the other side an high rock towered still. Spenser.My lord protector's hawks do tower so well. Shak.
tailstock: The sliding block or support, in a lathe, which carries thedead spindle, or adjustable center. The headstock supports the livespindle.
tameness: The quality or state of being tame.
tincture: One of the metals, colors, or furs used in armory.
tout: One who secretly watches race horses which are in course oftraining, to get information about their capabilities, for use inbetting. [Cant. Eng.]
tinsel: Showy to excess; gaudy; specious; superficial. "Tinseltrappings." Milton.
three-quarter: Measuring thirty inches by twenty-five; -- said ofportraitures. Three-quarter length, a portrait showing the figure tothe hips only.
theosophy: Any system of philosophy or mysticism which proposes to attainintercourse with God and superior spirits, and consequent superhumanknowledge, by physical processes, as by the theurgic operations ofsome ancient Platonists, or by the chemical processes of the Germanfire philosophers; also, a direct, as distinguished from a revealed,knowledge of God, supposed to be attained by extraordinaryillumination; especially, a direct insight into the processes of thedivine mind, and the interior relations of the divine nature.
tulip: Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa. Many varieties arecultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers. Tulip tree.(a) A large American tree bearing tuliplike flowers. SeeLiriodendron. (b) A West Indian malvaceous tree (Paritium, orHibiscus, tiliaceum).
topful: Full to the top, ore brim; brimfull. "Topful of direstcruelty." Shak.[He] was so topful of himself, that he let it spill on all thecompany. I. Watts.
taurocholic: Pertaining to, or designating, a conjugate acid (calledtaurocholic acid) composed of taurine and cholic acid, presentabundantly in human bile and in that of carnivora. It is exceedinglydeliquescent, and hence appears generally as a thick, gummy mass,easily soluble in water and alcohol. It has a bitter taste.
tempter: One who tempts or entices; especially, Satan, or the Devil,regarded as the great enticer to evil. "Those who are bent to dowickedly will never want tempters to urge them on." Tillotson.So glozed the Tempter, and his proem tuned. Milton.
tally: To check off, as parcels of freight going inboard or outboard.W. C. Russell. Tally on (Naut.), to dovetail together.
thermochrosy: The property possessed by heat of being composed, like light,of rays of different degrees of refrangibility, which are unequal inrate or degree of transmission through diathermic substances.
thermostable: Capable of being heated to or somewhat above 55º C. withoutloss of special properties; -- said of immune substances, etc.
trepanner: One who trepans. " Pitiful trepanners and impostors." Gauden.
tauromachian: Of or pertaining to bullfights.-- n.
tri-: A prefix (also used adjectively) denoting three proportional orcombining part, or the third degree of that to the name of which itis prefixed; as in trisulphide, trioxide, trichloride.
top-armor: A top railing supported by stanchions and equipped withnetting.
thermomotor: A heat engine; a hot-air engine.
treasury stock: Issued stock of an incorporated company held by the companyitself.
tarsectomy: The operation of excising one or more of the bones of thetarsus.
transcolation: Act of transcolating, or state of being transcolated. [Obs.]Bp. Stillingfleet.
tender-hefted: Having great tenderness; easily moved. [Obs.] Shak.
tichorrhine: A fossil rhinoceros with a vertical bony medial septumsupporting the nose; the hairy rhinoceros.
telescope bag: An adjustable traveling bag consisting of two cases, the largerslipping over the other.
testacy: The state or circumstance of being testate, or of leaving avalid will, or testament, at death.
trioecious: Having three sorts of flowers on the same or on differentplants, some of the flowers being staminate, others pistillate, andothers both staminate and pistillate; belonging to the orderTrioecia.
triassic: Of the age of, or pertaining to, the Trias.-- n.
thigmotaxis: The property possessed by living protoplasm of contracting, andthus moving, when touched by a solid or fluid substance.
thermae: Springs or baths of warm or hot water.
theme: A noun or verb, not modified by inflections; also, that part ofa noun or verb which remains unchanged (except by euphonicvariations) in declension or conjugation; stem.
temporariness: The quality or state of being temporary; -- opposed toperpetuity.
tristful: Sad; sorrowful; gloomy. Shak.Eyes so tristful, eyes so tristful, Heart so full of care and cumber.Longfellow.
trenchmore: A kind of lively dance of a rude, boisterous character. Also,music in triple time appropriate to the dance. [Obs.]All the windows in the town dance new trenchmore. Beau. & Fl.
tonsilar: Of or pertaining to the tonsils; tonsilitic. [Written alsotonsillar.]
testif: Testy; headstrong; obstinate. [Obs.]Testif they were and lusty for to play. Chaucer.
thimbleeye: The chub mackerel. See under Chub.
transpire: To pass off in the form of vapor or insensible perspiration; toexhale.
tuckahoe: A curious vegetable production of the Southern Atlantic UnitedStates, growing under ground like a truffle and often attainingimmense size. The real nature is unknown. Called also Indian bread,and Indian loaf.
twinned: Composed of parts united according to a law of twinning. SeeTwin, n., 4.
traject: To throw or cast through, over, or across; as, to traject thesun's light through three or more cross prisms. [R.] Sir I. Newton.
trona: A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutraland acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O, occurring as a whitecrystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs andlakes; -- called also urao, and by the ancients nitrum.
tarsal: Of or pertaining to the tarsus (either of the foot or eye).-- n.
thermoelectric: Pertaining to thermoelectricity; as, thermoelectric currents.
tricuspidate: Three-pointed; ending in three points; as, a tricuspidate leaf.
tenaculum: An instrument consisting of a fine, sharp hook attached to ahandle, and used mainly for taking up arteries, and the like.
thud: A dull sound without resonance, like that produced by strikingwith, or striking against, some comparatively soft substance; also,the stroke or blow producing such sound; as, the thrud of a cannonball striking the earth.At every new thud of the blast, a sob arose. Jeffrey.At intervals there came some tremendous thud on the side of thesteamer. C. Mackay.
trend: To have a particular direction; to run; to stretch; to tend;as, the shore of the sea trends to the southwest.
tenon: A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it,and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure togetherthe parts of a frame; especially, such a member when it passesentirely through the thickness of the piece in which the mortise iscut, and shows on the other side. Cf. Tooth, Tusk. Tenon saw, a sawwith a thin blade, usually stiffened by a brass or steel back, forcutting tenons. [Corruptly written tenant saw.] Gwilt.
tunny: Any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging tothe Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny (Orcynus orAlbacora thynnus) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the AtlanticOcean. It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and isextensively caught in the Mediterranean. On the American coast it iscalled horse mackerel. See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.[Written also thynny.]
torved: Stern; grim. See Torvous. [Obs.]But yesterday his breath Awed Rome, and his least torved frown wasdeath. J. Webster (1654).
tenet: Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which aperson holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or ofCicero.That al animals of the land are in their kind in the sea, . . . is atenet very questionable. Sir T. Browne.The religious tenets of his family he had early renounced withcontempt. Macaulay.
therefor: For that, or this; for it.With certain officers ordained therefore. Chaucer.
thymene: A liquid terpene obtained from oil of thyme.
turnspit: A small breed of dogs having a long body and short crookedlegs. These dogs were formerly much used for turning a spit on whichmeat was roasting.
trailing edge: A following edge. See Advancing edge, above.
tasco: A kind of clay for making melting pots. Percy Smith.
transcalency: The quality or state of being transcalent.
trigynia: A Linnæan order of plants having three pistils or styles.
tibiale: The bone or cartilage of the tarsus which articulates with thetibia and corresponds to a part of the astragalus in man and mostmammals.
tabling: The letting of one timber into another by alternate scores orprojections, as in shipbuilding.
telegraph: An apparatus, or a process, for communicating intelligencerapidly between distant points, especially by means of preconcertedvisible or audible signals representing words or ideas, or by meansof words and signs, transmitted by electrical action.
tewan: A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos ofNew Mexico and adjacent regions.
toller: A toll gatherer. "Tollers in markets." Piers Plowman.
tetrad: A tetravalent or quadrivalent atom or radical; as, carbon is atetrad.
teaseler: One who uses teasels for raising a nap on cloth. [Written alsoteaseller, teasler.]
true-hearted: Of a faithful heart; honest; sincere; not faithless ordeceitful; as, a truhearted friend.-- True"-heart`ed*ness, n.
tidings: Account of what has taken place, and was not before known;news.I shall make my master glad with these tidings. Shak.Full well the busy whisper, circling round, Conveyed the dismaltidings when he frowned. Goldsmith.
triglyph: An ornament in the frieze of the Doric order, repeated at equalintervals. Each triglyph consists of a rectangular tablet, slightlyprojecting, and divided nearly to the top by two parallel andperpendicular gutters, or channels, called glyphs, into three parts,or spaces, called femora. A half channel, or glyph, is also cut uponeach of the perpendicular edges of the tablet. See Illust. ofEntablature.
taborer: One who plays on the tabor. Shak.
thermometry: The estimation of temperature by the use of a thermometricapparatus.
trample: The act of treading under foot; also, the sound produced bytrampling. Milton.The huddling trample of a drove of sheep. Lowell.
technical: Of or pertaining to the useful or mechanic arts, or to anyscience, business, or the like; specially appropriate to any art,science, or business; as, the words of an indictment must betechnical. Blackstone.
tennysonian: Of or pertaining to Alfred (Lord) Tennyson, the English poet(1809-92); resembling, or having some of the characteristics of, hispoetry, as simplicity, pictorial quality, sensuousness, etc.
trapezohedral: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a trapezohedron.
tozy: Soft, like wool that has been teased.-- To"zi*ness, n.
titular: Existing in title or name only; nominal; having the title to anoffice or dignity without discharging its appropriate duties; as, atitular prince.If these magnificent titles yet remain Not merely titular. Milton.Titular bishop. See under Bishop.
troching: One of the small branches of a stag's antler.
tawery: A place where skins are tawed.
tipulary: Of or pertaining to the tipulas.
threatening: a. & n. from Threaten, v.-- Threat"en*ing*ly, adv. Threatening letters (Law), letterscontaining threats, especially those designed to extort money, or toobtain other property, by menaces; blackmailing letters.
top-rope: A rope used for hoisting and lowering a topmast, and for otherpurposes.
trillion: According to the French notation, which is used upon theContinent generally and in the United States, the number expressed bya unit with twelve ciphers annexed; a million millions; according tothe English notation, the number produced by involving a million tothe third power, or the number represented by a unit with eighteenciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
triquadrantal: Having three quadrants; thus, a triquadrantal triangle is onewhose three sides are quadrants, and whose three angles areconsequently right angles.
totalize: To make total, or complete;to reduce to completeness.Coleridge.
tartralic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained as a whiteamorphous deliquescent substance, C8H10O11; -- called alsoditartaric, tartrilic, or tartrylic acid.
trunk piston: In a single-acting engine, an elongated hollow piston, open atthe end, in which the end of the connecting rod is pivoted. Thepiston rod, crosshead and stuffing box are thus dispensed with.
torose: Cylindrical with alternate swellings and contractions; havingthe surface covered with rounded prominences.
topless: Having no top, or no visble fop; hence, fig.: very lofty;supreme; unequaled. " The topless Apennines." "Topless fortunes."Beau. & Fl.
trigastric: Having three bellies; -- said of a muscle. Dunglison.
timepleaser: One who complies with prevailing opinions, whatever they maybe; a timeserver.Timepleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness. Shak.
tabefaction: A wasting away; a gradual losing of flesh by disease.
tarantism: A nervous affection producing melancholy, stupor, and anuncontrollable desire to dance. It was supposed to be produced by thebite of the tarantula, and considered to be incapable of cure exceptby protraced dancing to appropriate music. [Written also tarentism.]
translate: To remove, as a bishop, from one see to another. "Fisher,Bishop of Rochester, when the king would have translated him fromthat poor bishopric to a better, . . . refused." Camden.
trice: To haul and tie up by means of a rope.
theomancy: A kind of divination drawn from the responses of oracles amongheathen nations.
towser: A familiar name for a dog. [ Written also Towzer. ]
theroid: Resembling a beast in nature or habit; marked by animalcharacteristics; as, theroid idiocy.
tallage: To lay an impost upon; to cause to pay tallage.
tweak: To pinch and pull with a sudden jerk and twist; to twitch; as,to tweak the nose. Shak.
timaline: Of or pertaining to the genus Timalus or family Timalidæ, whichincludes the babblers thrushes, and bulbuls.
tuberose: A plant (Polianthes tuberosa) with a tuberous root and aliliaceous flower. It is much cultivated for its beautiful andfragrant white blossoms.
tempo: The rate or degree of movement in time. A tempo giusto(joos"to) Etym: [It.], in exact time; -- sometimes, directing areturn to strict time after a tempo rubato.-- Tempo rubato. See under Rubato.
turtle peg: A sharp steel spear attached to a cord, used in taking seaturtles. -- Turtle pegging.
table work: Typesetting of tabular nmatter, or the type matter set intabular form.
trisulc: Something having three forks or prongs, as a trident. [Obs.]"Jupiter's trisulc." Sir T. Browne.
tuberculosis: A constitutional disease characterized by the production oftubercles in the internal organs, and especially in the lungs, whereit constitutes the most common variety of pulmonary consumption.
traducement: The act of traducing; misrepresentation; ill-founded censure;defamation; calumny. [R.] Shak.
taenidium: The chitinous fiber forming the spiral thread of the tracheæ ofinsects. See Illust. of Trachea.
tootle: To toot gently, repeatedly, or continuously, on a windinstrument, as a flute; also, to make a similar noise by any means."The tootling robin."  John Clare.
toyer: One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
trias: The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and sonamed by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata,which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, andKeuper.
truce: A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposingforces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation orother purpose; an armistice.
trophi: The mouth parts of an insect, collectively, including thelabrum, labium, maxillæ, mandibles, and lingua, with theirappendages.
trochilics: The science of rotary motion, or of wheel work. Wilkins.
traitorly: Like a traitor; treacherous; traitorous. [Obs.] "Traitorlyrascals." Shak.
truckle: A small wheel or caster. Hudibras.
tolane: A hydrocarbon, C14H10, related both to the acetylene and thearomatic series, and produced artificially as a white crystallinesubstance; -- called also diphenyl acetylene.
torsel: A plate of timber for the end of a beam or joist to rest on.Gwilt
torricellian: Of or pertaining to Torricelli, an Italian philosopher andmathematician, who, in 1643, discovered that the rise of a liquid ina tube, as in the barometer, is due to atmospheric pressure. SeeBarometer. Torricellian tube, a glass tube thirty or more inches inlength, open at the lower end and hermetically sealed at the upper,such as is used in the barometer.-- Torricellian vacuum (Physics), a vacuum produced by filling witha fluid, as mercury, a tube hermetically closed at one end, and,after immersing the other end in a vessel of the same fluid, allowingthe inclosed fluid to descend till it is counterbalanced by thepressure of the atmosphere, as in the barometer. Hutton.
tylosis: An intrusion of one vegetable cell into the cavity of another,sometimes forming there an irregular mass of cells. Goodale.
topology: The art of, or method for, assisting the memory by associatingthe thing or subject to be remembered with some place. [R.]
temporarily: In a temporary manner; for a time.
typification: The act of typifying, or representing by a figure.
tardigrada: A tribe of edentates comprising the sloths. They are noted forthe slowness of their movements when on the ground. See Sloth, 3.
tornado: A violent whirling wind; specifically (Meteorol.), a tempestdistinguished by a rapid whirling and slow progressive motion,usually accompaned with severe thunder, lightning, and torrents ofrain, and commonly of short duration and small breadth; a smallcyclone.
toe: One of the terminal members, or digits, of the foot of a man oran animal. "Each one, tripping on his toe." Shak.
transnatation: The act of swimming across, as a river.
trackwalker: A person employed to walk over and inspect a section of tracks.
tithable: Subject to the payment of tithes; as, tithable lands.
tritovum: An embryonic insect which has twice cast its skin previous tohatching from the egg.
tonguefish: A flounder (Symphurus plagiusa) native of the southern coast ofthe United States.
telegrapher: One who sends telegraphic messages; a telegraphic operator; atelegraphist.
torosity: The quality or state of being torose.
tortuous: Oblique; -- applied to the six signs of the zodiac (fromCapricorn to Gemini) which ascend most rapidly and obliquely. [Obs.]Skeat.Infortunate ascendent tortuous. Chaucer.--Tor"tu*ous*ly, adv.-- Tor"tu*ous*ness, n.
turnover: Admitting of being turned over; made to be turned over; as, aturnover collar, etc.
tetramorph: The union of the four attributes of the Evangelists in onefigure, which is represented as winged, and standing on winged fierywheels, the wings being covered with eyes. The representations of itare evidently suggested by the vision of Ezekiel (ch. i.)
tierce: The third tone of the scale. See Mediant.
touching: Affecting; moving; pathetic; as, a touching tale.-- Touch"ing*ly, adv.
terrific: Causing terror; adapted to excite great fear or dread;terrible; as, a terrific form; a terrific sight.
turbination: The act of spinning or whirling, as a top.
trichromatic: Having or existing in three different phases of color; havingthree distinct color varieties; -- said of certain birds and insects.
torteau: A roundel of a red color.
tharms: Twisted guts. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Ascham.
teeter-tail: The spotted sandpiper. See the Note under Sandpiper.
theophanic: Of or pertaining to a theopany; appearing to man, as a god.
tenable: Capable of being held, naintained, or defended, as against anassailant or objector, or againts attempts to take or process; as, atenable fortress, a tenable argument.If you have hitherto concealed his sight, Let it be tenable in yoursilence still. Shak.I would be the last man in the world to give up his cause when it wastenable. Sir W. Scott.
transprose: To change from prose into verse; to versify; also, to changefrom verse into prose. [Obs.] Dryden.
tillman: A man who tills the earth; a husbandman. [Obs.] Tusser.
trestletree: One of two strong bars of timber, fixed horizontally on theopposite sides of the masthead, to support the crosstrees and theframe of the top; -- generally used in the plural. Totten.
trivalent: Having a valence of three; capable of being combined with,substituted for, or compared with, three atoms of hydrogen; -- saidof triad atoms or radicals; thus, nitrogen is trivalent in ammonia.
telephote: A telelectric apparatus for producing images of visible objectsat a distance.
theatral: Of or pertaining to a theater; theatrical. [Obs.]
taleteller: One who tells tales or stories, especially in a mischievous orofficious manner; a talebearer; a telltale; a tattler.
trout-colored: White, with spots of black, bay, or sorrel; as, a trout-coloredhorse.
trunkfish: Any one of several species of plectognath fishes, belonging tothe genus Ostracion, or the family Ostraciontidæ, having an angularbody covered with a rigid integument consisting of bony scales. Someof the species are called also coffer fish, and boxfish.
tucuma: A Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum Tucuma) which furnishes an ediblefruit.
tamarin: Any one of several species of small squirrel-like SouthAmerican monkeys of the genus Midas, especially M. ursulus.
tentation: A mode of adjusting or operating by repeated trials orexperiments. Knight.
transdialect: To change or translate from one dialect into another. [R.] Bp.Warburton.
trial: The formal examination of the matter in issue in a cause beforea competent tribunal; the mode of determining a question of fact in acourt of law; the examination, in legal form, of the facts in issuein a cause pending before a competent tribunal, for the purpose ofdetermining such issue.
thermophore: An apparatus for conveying heat, as a case containing materialwhich retains its heat for a considerable period.
tophet: A place lying east or southeast of Jerusalem, in the valley ofHinnom. [Written also Topheth.]And he defiled Topheth, which is in the valley of the children ofHinnom. 2 Kings xxiii. 10.
tidytips: A California composite plant (Layia platyglossa), the flower ofwhich has yellow rays tipped with white.
tuberculocidin: A special substance contained in tuberculin, supposed to be theactive agent of the latter freed from various impurities.
thankworthy: Deserving thanks; worthy of gratitude; mreitorious.For this thankworthy, if a man, for conscience toward God, enduregrief, suffering wrongfully. 1 Pet. ii. 19.
tiny: Very small; little; puny.When that I was and a little tiny boy. Shak.
teenage: The longer wood for making or mending fences. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
thoroughly: In a thorough manner; fully; entirely; completely.
tabularization: The act of tabularizing, or the state of being tabularized;formation into tables; tabulation.
trilobita: An extinct order of arthropods comprising the trilobites.
toadstool: A name given to many umbrella-shaped fungi, mostly of the genusAgaricus. The species are almost numberless. They grow on decayingorganic matter.
tipstock: The detachable or movable fore part of a gunstock, lyingbeneath the barrel or barrels, and forming a hold for the left hand.
timid: Wanting courage to meet danger; easily frightened; timorous;not bold; fearful; shy.Poor is the triumph o'er the timid hare. Thomson.
thoroughstitch: So as to go the whole length of any business; fully;completely. [Obs.]Preservance alone can carry us thoroughstitch. L'Estrange.
total: Whole; not divided; entire; full; complete; absolute; as, atotal departure from the evidence; a total loss. " Total darkness.""To undergo myself the total crime." Milton. Total abstinence. SeeAbstinence, n., 1.-- Total depravity. (Theol.) See Original sin, under Original.
transpierce: To pierce through; to penetrate; to permeate; to pass through.The sides transpierced return a rattling sound. Dryden.
trap shooting: Shooting at pigeons liberated, or glass balls or clay pigeonssprung into the air, from a trap. -- Trap shooter.
tetrachotomous: Having a division by fours; separated into four parts orseries, or into series of fours.
temporary: Lasting for a time only; existing or continuing for a limitedtime; not permanent; as, the patient has obtained temporary relief.Temporary government of the city. Motley.Temporary star. (Astron.) See under Star.
turningness: The quality of turning; instability; tergiversation. [Obs.] SirP. Sidney.
temper: To bring to a proper degree of hardness; as, to temper iron orsteel.The tempered metals clash, and yield a silver sound. Dryden.
trackage: The act of tracking, or towing, as a boat; towage.
taurid: Any of a group of meteors appearing November 20-23; -- socalled because they appear to radiate from a point in Taurus.
tercine: A cellular layer derived from the nucleus of an ovule andsurrounding the embryo sac. Cf. Quintine.
turrel: A certain tool used by coopers. Sherwood.
tranquil: Quiet; calm; undisturbed; peaceful; not agitated; as, theatmosphere is tranquil; the condition of the country is tranquil.A style clear, tranquil, easy to follow. De Quincey.
trimester: A term or period of three months.
tainture: Taint; tinge; difilement; stain; spot. [R.] Shak.
trysail: A fore-and-aft sail, bent to a gaff, and hoisted on a lowermast or on a small mast, called the trysail mast, close abaft a lowermast; -- used chiefly as a storm sail. Called also spencer. Totten.
